# The Influence of Labor Market Power in the Audit Profession  

## Abstract  

This paper examines the influence of labor market power in the audit profession. Using a dataset of online job postings, we confirm that audit offices in more concentrated labor markets have greater labor market power and exercise it in the form of higher skill requirements and greater required effort from their auditors, at similar or slightly lower wages. We then show that client firms of audit offices in more concentrated labor markets are less likely to restate their earnings and have lower absolute discretionary accruals. These findings are only present when employees have lower mobility across professions and geographies, consistent with audit offices’ power in the local labor market explaining the results. Collectively, our findings highlight the importance of labor market power in understanding audit quality.  

JEL: J31, J40, J42, M42, M55  

Keywords: Audit Profession; Labor Market Power; Monopsony and Oligopsony; Wages; Skills; Effort; Audit Quality  

### 1. INTRODUCTION  

This study investigates the consequences of labor market power in the assurance profession in terms of employment conditions and audit quality. Labor market power is a phenomenon in which reduced competition in the labor market leads to an upward-sloping labor supply curve and gives employers increased bargaining power over their employees, as workers in these markets have limited outside options (Robinson 1969; Boal and Ransom 1997). Labor market power allows companies to require more skills from workers, increase retention, and/or reduce labor costs (Berger, Herkenhoff, and Mongey 2022; Benmelech, Bergman, and Kim 2022). Several academic papers and recent court cases focus on barriers to geographic mobility and document the existence of local labor market power in both lowerand higher-skilled occupations, including academia, and policy makers are increasingly paying attention to the issue (e.g., Staiger, Spetz, and Phibbs 2010; Ashenfelter, Farber, and Ransom  

2010; Falch 2010; Ransom and Sims 2010; Dube, Lester, and Reich 2016; CEA 2016; Delrahim 2019). However, little is known about the influence of labor market power on individual employers? economic outputs. In this paper, we use unique datasets to investigate labor market power in the audit profession and study its effect on audit quality.  

The audit setting is particularly suitable given that the profession is knowledgeintensive, with human capital being one of its most important assets (Knechel 2010; Lennox and Wu 2018; Aobdia, Srivastava, and Wang 2018; Aobdia 2019a).2 The audit market is also heavily concentrated (e.g., Gerakos and Syverson 2015), and the Big 4 firms hire the bulk of accounting graduates in the U.S. (Moritz 2014; Nieh 2016; Lee, Naiker, and Stewart 2022). Moreover, decreases in migration rates for graduates in the U.S. (e.g., Gottlieb and Joseph 2006; Ishitani 2011; Molloy, Smith, and Wozniak 2011), local recruiting strategies adopted by public accounting firms (Lee et al. 2022), mandated experience requirements in the assurance profession to obtain a CPA license, and interstate barriers to moving resulting from CPA licensing restrictions can make individuals with the skill set to become auditors more dependent on local offices of public accounting firms. Theoretical models of labor market oligopsony suggest that if accounting professionals experience significant costs when transitioning among employers for whom they might work, or audit firms take each other's recruiting strategies as given (e.g., a la Cournot) in their recruiting practices, then labor market power should exist in the audit profession (e.g., Boal and Ransom 1997).  

Building on the insight of the labor economics literature that labor market power is characterized by a departure of wages from the marginal product of labor, we expect audit firms to use their labor market power in several non-exclusive ways. First, audit firms with greater labor market power could pay similar wages but recruit more skilled and thus more productive auditors, because these auditors have limited outside options and lower bargaining power. Consistent with this argument, Hershbein, Macaluso, and Yeh (2019) find greater demand for skills in more concentrated labor markets. Second, labor market power can change individual auditors? incentives to exert costly effort. For example, Shapiro and Stiglitz (1984) show that paying employees higher wages relative to outside options raises the cost of job loss for employees, thereby giving them stronger incentives to exert costly effort. The incentive effect stemming from the threat of termination is greater when wages are higher and when the value of outside options is lower (Shapiro and Stiglitz 1984; Katz 1986). Thus, limited outside options associated with higher labor market power can lead to greater effort.? Third, an audit office with greater labor market power could recruit similarly skilled auditors and require unchanged effort from them, but pay them lower wages instead, consistent with the labor economics literature that finds negative associations between labor market concentration and wages (Azar, Marinescu, Steinbaum, and Taska 2020; Benmelech et al. 2022).  

Depending on how audit offices use their labor market power, the effects of such power on audit quality is not clear ex-ante. If audit offices with higher labor market power have higher skill and effort requirements and pay similar or moderately lower wages, we should expect a positive relation between labor market power and audit quality, because auditors who are more skilled and exert greater effort should be more productive. If audit offices with greater labor market power hire similarly skilled auditors and require unchanged effort from them, but pay them lower wages instead, we would expect no relation between labor market power and audit quality. In addition, if audit offices reduce wages too much, auditor skills and effort may even decrease. While this outcome is unlikely, it would result in lower audit quality. Overall, the effect of labor market power on audit quality remains an empirical question.  

To test our research questions, we follow several studies in the labor economics literature and employ data from Burning Glass Technologies (hereafter BGT) to measure the potential for local labor market power (Hershbein et al. 2019; Azar et al. 2020). BGT data cover the near-universe of audit firms′ online job postings from 2010 to 2017.4 Based on the theoretical predictions in Boal and Ransom (1997) and Hershbein et al. (2019) as well as empirical studies by Azar et al. (2020) and Benmelech et al. (2022), we use the HerfindahlHirschman Index constructed by job postings in the local area as the proxy for labor market power and expect the potential for labor market power to be greater in more concentrated labor markets. The auditor labor market power measure is based on the 134,511 audit-related job positions posted by the top 50 audit firms in the United States from 2010 through 2017. The inter-region correlation of this measure is a low five percent, indicating substantial variation across different regions. Its mean and median are 0.2684 and 0.2552, respectively. According to the guidelines specified by the U.S. Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission, a labor market with a Herfindahl index greater than 0.25 is \*“highly concentrated."" In the empirical analyses, we focus on Big 4 auditors given that they might target different types of graduates relative to smaller audit firms.  

We next provide evidence on how audit firms use labor market power. As discussed above, an audit firm with labor market power can use a combination of higher skill requirements, higher effort requirements, and lower wages. First, we use skill requirements in online job postings and find positive associations between labor market concentration and the number of skill categories, soft skills, and education requirements in job postings.° Second, while we acknowledge that measuring audit effort is difficult and that our measure is inevitably noisy, we use as proxies for audit effort the number of employees in an audit office divided by the total assets audited or by total audit fees. The underlying concept is that audit firms expect their employees to exercise effort along two dimensions, quantity and quality. While we cannot directly measure the quality of effort, these proxies can capture whether employees conduct greater proportions of audits and thus serve as indicators of the quantity of effort. These proxies can also suggest higher expected quality of effort so long as the expectations for effort quantity and for effort quality are positively correlated.7 We find that labor concentration is negatively related to these two ratios and their natural logarithms, consistent with greater effort requirements for individual auditors when labor concentration is higher, suggesting a potential departure of wages from marginal product of labor. Third, we examine the relation between audit offices? labor market concentration and wages offered on audit positions using wage data from labor condition applications filed with the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL). We do not find that labor market concentration is significantly related to wages offered to audit personnel in the cross-section. Untabulated supplemental analyses indicate that it is negatively related to wages offered in the time series, but the effect is modest.8 Overall, our evidence suggests that audit offices in more concentrated labor markets are more interested in recruiting more productive audit personnel and requiring increased effort from them, rather than in reducing their wages by significant amounts. Thus, we expect to find positive associations between labor market power and audit quality, which we study next.  

We use two commonly accepted proxies for audit quality, restatements and absolute discretionary accruals (e.g., DeFond and Zhang 2014; Aobdia 2019b), and find negative associations between labor market concentration and these measures. The results are robust to a battery of tests and additional controls in the regressions, such as measures of office size, product market competition, and the number of local universities with accounting programs. An increase in audit offices? labor market power from the $25^{\mathrm{th}}$ to the $75^{\mathrm{th}}$ percentile is associated with a decrease of 1.2 percentage points in the probability of restatement. These results are consistent with audit offices with greater labor market power providing higher-quality audits.  

We conduct several cross-sectional analyses to provide additional evidence that the positive relation between labor market concentration and audit quality is driven by audit offices? labor market power and not by alternative explanations. Specifically, we consider the effect of barriers to mobility across professions and geographies.9 If our results are driven by labor market power, they should be weaker when barriers to mobility are lower and thus employees have a higher value of outside options (e.g., Ransom 1993; Boal and Ransom 1997). Individual auditors can seek employment in audit- or tax-related positions in local public companies, in tax or consulting positions within the local Big 4 audit offices, and in finance positions. Using four different proxies for local substitute employment opportunities from these positions, we find that the positive associations between labor market concentration and audit quality are only present in the subsamples with fewer local substitute employment opportunities. Moreover, as suggested by Kodrzycki (2001) and Gottlieb and Joseph (2006), ge0graphic mobility is likely lower when a local area is more remote, when its quality of life is higher, or when net migration rates to this area are higher. Using these three proxies of geographic mobility, we find that the relations between labor market concentration and audit quality are only present for audit offices in areas with lower geographic mobility. Taken together, these analyses suggest that the effect of labor market power on audit quality is only present when substitute local employment opportunities are limited and when the workforce with the skill set to work in auditing is less geographically mobile.10  

In supplemental tests, we find that the effect of labor market power on audit quality is present only for audit offices whose labor market share within the local area is above the median, consistent with the idea that audit offices with more desirable characteristics can more easily exercise labor market power. We also find that the effect of labor market power on audit quality is present only in the auditor labor market with experience requirements greater than three years. This result is consistent with increased effort by mid-career auditors having more influence on the overall quality of an audit relative to entry-level auditors and adds to an emerging literature that highlights the importance of mid-career auditors on audit quality (e.g., Kornberger, Justesen, and Mouritsen 2011; Aobdia, Choudhary, and Newberger 2023).11  

Our study extends the literature along several dimensions. We contribute to the literature on labor markets in auditing and respond to the observation by Causholli et al. (2011, 206) that “little research has addressed the structure or dynamics of the labor market in auditing other than to observe that it is somewhat cyclical.? Limited studies in this area include Beck, Francis, and Gunn (2018), who show that audit quality is higher in cities with higher average educational level, Lee et al. (2022), who find a positive association between audit offices\* proximity to key feeder universities and audit quality, and Barrios (2022), who finds that the 150-hour rule for CPA licensing reduces the number of entrants into the audit profession but does little in improving the overall quality of the auditor labor market. These studies focus on the supply of labor, whereas we focus on the demand for labor and how demand concentration affects auditor employment conditions and audit quality. Focusing on the demand for labor in an auditing context is important, as highlighted in a recent presentation by Martin Schmalz (Chief Economist at the PCAOB) at the 2024 Auditing Section Midyear Meeting. Schmalz (2024) mentions that the current “talent crisis"’ in auditing can have a demand explanation, citing an earlier version of this paper to highlight the role of monopsony power as a potential explanation. Our study is also related to Hoopes, Merkley, Pacelli, and Schroeder (2018), who, assuming that wages are exogenously given, find a positive association between auditor wages and audit quality. In contrast, we focus on the extent by which concentration in the demand for professionals with the skills to become auditors influences auditor skills, effort, wages, and eventually audit quality.12  

More generally, our study contributes to a growing literature in labor economics which documents that some employers exhibit substantial power in the labor market (Staiger et al. 2010; Falch 2010; Ransom and Sims 2010; Matsudaira 2013), and that firms with labor market power pay lower wages (Azar et al. 2020; Benmelech et al. 2022) and require higher skills (Hershbein et al. 2019). We find evidence consistent with these ideas in the audit profession and extend the literature by focusing on the influence of labor market power on effort required from employees and individual employers? outputs. Our evidence suggests that greater labor market power can, at least in the short run, help audit firms improve their quality, and that increased skills and effort can be mechanisms by which firms do so.  

## II. LITERATURE AND HYPOTHESIS  

# The Importance of Human Capital in the Audit Profession  

Recent archival literature highlights the importance of individual auditors and human capital for audit quality. A growing literature finds that individual partners influence the quality of the audits they lead (e.g., Gul, Wu, and Yang 2013; Aobdia, Lin, and Petacchi 2015; Knechel, Vanstraelen, and Zerni 2015; Lennox and Wu 2018). While limited, the literature on audit team members below the lead partner also finds that they significantly influence audit quality (e.g. Kornberger et al. 2011; Carter and Spence 2014; Westermann, Bedard, and Earley 2015; Bol, Estep, Moers, and Peecher 2018; Contessotto, Knechel, and Moroney 2019; Aobdia et al. 2023).  

In contrast, the literature on the factors that affect the supply and demand for human capital in the audit profession remains limited. Aobdia et al. (2018) find that foreign-born graduates contribute to the profession's human capital. Cascino, Tamayo, and Vetter (2021) find that after the adoption of CPA mobility provisions, the wages of accounting professionals decrease, while employment levels are unaffected. Studies by Beck et al. (2018), Hoopes et al. (2018), and Lee et al. (2022), discussed above, also focus on the effect of local supply characteristics and auditor wages on audit quality. Overall, the characteristics of local demand for human capital in the audit profession and its impact on audit quality are not well understood.  

# Labor Market Power and the Auditing Profession  

### Labor market power  

The labor economics literature has increasingly paid attention to the concept of labor market monopsony and labor market power, whereby reduced competition for talent among firms shifts the bargaining balance toward employers (Boal and Random 1997; Ashenfelter et al. 2010; Manning 2011; CEA 2016). A growing literature documents evidence of declining competition for labor in the U.s., and recent anecdotes and court cases confirm that local labor market power exists in both lower- and higher-skilled occupations, including nursing, technology, and academia (e.g., Delrahim 2019; Satisky 2019).  

Many characteristics of the auditing profession suggest that labor market power exists. The market for auditing services is concentrated (e.g., Gerakos and Syverson 2015). The Big 4 firms hire the bulk of accounting graduates in the U.S. (Moritz 2014; Nieh 2016; Lee et al. 2022), which suggests that local alternate employment opportunities are limited, at least for those with less experience. Magnifying the need for accounting graduates to work in public accounting firms, most U.S. states impose experience requirements in accounting-related fields to grant CPA licenses (e.g., Armitage 2014). Further, public accounting firms typically adopt local recruiting strategies, hiring mostly within a 60-mile radius (Lee et al. 2022). Local hiring could limit the geographic mobility of accounting graduates, similar to other professions, such as schoolteachers, academics, and nurses, where the effect of local labor market power has empirically been documented (Luizer and Thornton 1986; Ransom 1993; Hirsch and Schumacher 1995). Theories of monopsony power suggest that under such conditions, local labor market power can exist in the audit profession (Boal and Ransom 1997).  

Nevertheless, the AICPA has for more than 20 years highlighted the search for talent as the top concern of audit firms (Drew 2015). This concern has intensified recently due to more early-career CPAs leaving public accounting firms (Hermanson, Houston, Stefaniak, and Wilkins 2016). Moreover, alternate career opportunities for individuals with the skills to become auditors exist, including corporate positions and consulting or tax positions within public accounting or other firms (e.g., Hoopes et al. 2018). Some professionals, particularly new graduates in search of a first position, might also find it easier to initially move across different geographies. 13 If audit firms intensely compete for talent, or the labor force is geographically mobile, labor market power in the audit profession might be lower than anticipated.  

Theoretically, labor market power results from employers facing upward-sloping labor supply. Profit maximization leads them to pay wages lower than their marginal revenue product, because of the need to raise wages for all employees if employers try to hire another employee requiring a higher wage (e.g., Boal and Ransom 1997). This departure of wages from marginal revenue product is absent when labor markets are competitive and employers are price takers.  

To explore how audit offices use labor market power and illustrate the different forces at play, we propose the following theoretical framework, which adapts and expands Shapiro and Stiglitz (1984).14 Suppose that risk-neutral employees receive wages $W$ , and have the possibility to either shirk, or provide effort at cost $e$ . If employees shirk, they are caught with probability $p$ and fired, having to resort to their outside option $V(L M P,s)$ , which decreases in local labor market power LMP, and increases in their skills $s$ . Employees net utility if they do not shirk is their pay less the cost of their effort, $W{-}e$ , and if they shirk is $p V(L M P,s){+}(I{-}p)W$ The latter is a weighted average in utilities depending on whether the employee is caught shirking. In equilibrium, the employer sets wages $W$ such that workers are indifferent between providing costly effort or shirking, that is, $W{-}e{=}p V(L M P,s){+}(I{-}p)W_{\cdot}$ or $p W{-}e{=}p V(L M P,s)$ (1). Doing so minimizes wages paid but nevertheless ensures provision of costly effort.  

Comparative statics from Equation (1) yield the following observations: when labor market power LMP is greater, the value of the outside option $V(L M P,s)$ is lower, and to satisfy Equation (1), ceteris paribus the employer can reduce wages $W$ , or set higher effort $e$ for the employees, or require more skills from employees (i.e., increase $s$ ).15 Thus, we first study audit offices? skill requirements, effort, and wages to shed light on whether and how audit offices use labor market power and answer the following research question.  

RQ1: What are the consequences of local labor market power in the auditing profession, if any, in terms of skill and effort requirements and wages?  

### Potential effect on audit quality  

Based on Equation (1), employers with greater labor market power can require greater skills and/or greater effort from prospective and incumbent employees without increasing wages, or require similar skills and effort at lower wages. Thus, labor market power can affect audit quality through two mechanisms, a change in the skills and a change in the effort of individual auditors. Greater skills and effort likely increase audit quality, but whether greater labor market power leads to greater skills and effort is uncertain, because employers also have an opportunity to hire similarly skilled employees at lower wages. We also note that if employers reduce wages too much, then skills and effort would decrease. But this is unlikely to be a credible equilibrium in practice, because otherwise audit offices with lower labor market power would also likely reduce skills and effort to pay lower wages. Furthermore, it might take some time for newly hired auditors with greater skills to significantly influence the audit quality of an office, if previously hired auditors have different skill levels and acquiring new skills is more difficult for them. In contrast, an office with an increase in labor market power and thus in bargaining power can immediately require all auditors, including those that were previously hired, to increase effort. Overall, based on this framework, the ex-ante effect of labor market power on audit quality is somewhat unclear and depends on the extent by which auditors with labor market power require greater skills or ask for greater effort from employees, or reduce wages. However, given that the costs of employee skills and effort decrease with labor market power (i.e., employers with greater labor market power can use the same wage to buy higher skills and effort),it seems reasonable to expect employee skills and effort to increase or at least remain the same with labor market power in equilibrium. That is, two likely scenarios are that employers with labor market power moderately reduce wages or keep wages constant while increasing skills and effort, resulting in higher audit quality, or reduce wages while keeping effort and skills the same. We state our hypothesis in its alternative form:  

H1: Audit offices with greater labor market power provide higher-quality audits.  

Overall, labor market power may affect wages, skills, and required effort. Changes in skills and required effort should ultimately influence audit quality. We thus initially focus on these relations, and next examine cross-sectional settings in which local labor market power is expected to be more salient. Evidence from these tests can shed light on whether and how labor market power affects audit quality and mitigate omitted variable and endogeneity concerns.  

## III. DATA, KEY MEASURES, AND SAMPLE  

### Job Posting Data  

We use job posting data provided by Burning Glass Technologies Inc. Over the past decade, online posting has become the major channel by which firms circulate job openings, with a boom in job posting sites, such as Indeed, Glassdoor, and Career Builder. Starting from 2010, BGT has tracked and collected job postings from about 40,000 job search platforms as well as directly from U.S. companies’ websites. Over this period, BGT recorded a total of 3,670,517,432 postings, de-duplicated for identical job postings that were posted on multiple sites. Given the breadth of its coverage, the BGT data are more comprehensive than data from any single job posting site, such as CareerBuilder (Hershbein and Kahn 2018).  

BGT extracts several data items from job postings, including employer name, posting date, title, location, occupation, skills or certification required, and minimum education or experience. The BGT job posting data have been used in labor economics (e.g., Azar et al. 2020; Deming and Kahn 2018; Hershbein and Kahn 2018). In contrast to these studies, which focus on aggregated labor markets, we study a specific labor market segment—the auditor labor market. This setting is particularly suitable because human capital constitutes an audit firm's most important asset, personnel hired by audit firms tends to be more homogenous than those hired by industrial and financial firms, and output measures of audit quality are available.  

### Measure of Auditor Labor Market Power  

We rely on the top 50 audit firms from 2010 to 2017 to construct a measure of auditor labor market power. We manually match the top 50 audit firms to BGT employers by name and obtain exact matches for 47 of the 50 audit firms.16 We exclude BGT employers that are related to these audit firms but have names pointing towards non-auditing services, such as tax and advisory (e.g., “PWC ADVISORY SERVICES"). We then retrieve all the job postings of the matched audit firms between 2010-2017 and keep only audit-related positions, which are defined as job postings with one of the following keywords in the job title: “audit, “auditing," "assurance,”“accounting,”“account,” “accountant,” and “accountancy”, or identified with Standard Occupational Classification (SOC) code “13-2011" (i.e., the occupation of "accountants and auditors").17 During our sample period, these top audit firms posted a total of  

134,511 audit positions. The key information in a job posting is job location, particularly the state and county of a job. Among the 98,834 job postings of Big 4 auditors, only 0.2 percent of them have missing county-level location information. We then match the state and county associated with every job posting to its corresponding Core-Based Statistical Area (CBSA).  

Following Azar et al. (2020), we measure labor market power as the HerfindahlHirschman Index (HHI) of the labor market at the CBSA-year level. We first calculate the share of auditor i's job postings in CBSA $j$ and year $t$ , equal to the total number of audit-related job vacancies that auditor $i$ posts in CBSA $j$ and year $t$ divided by the total number of auditrelated job vacancies posted by all top audit firms in CBSA $j$ and year $t.$ We then sum the squared shares to derive the labor market HHI. The formula can be described as follows.  

$$
L a b o r\_M a r k e t\_H H I_{j,t}=\sum_{i}^{I}{S h a r e^{2}}_{i,j,t}
$$  

where $S h a r e_{i,j,t}$ is the share of auditor i's job postings in CBSA $j$ and year $t$ .This measure captures the concentration of auditor labor market in each local area and year. Based on the theoretical predictions in Boal and Ransom (1997) and Hershbein et al. (2019) and empirical studies by Azar et al. (2020) and Benmelech et al. (2022), audit offices in more concentrated labor markets (higher labor market HHI) are expected to have higher labor market power. For example, during our sample period, Baton Rouge, LA (Tulsa, OK) has a labor market HHI of 0.8414 (0.1645) and thus should have a highly concentrated (more competitive) auditor labor market. Note that the labor market HHI of a given CBSA and year is determined by the interplay among all audit firms with a presence in the same locality, rather than by any single audit firm. Thus, the effects of labor market HHI are less likely to be confounded by characteristics of individual audit firms. Auditor labor market HHI is autocorrelated at about 50 percent, consistent with concentration representing a reasonably persistent attribute of a local labor market (untabulated). Given that there is substantial variation in auditor labor market power across CBSAs, as shown in Table 1, and relatively limited time-series variation over eight years of data, our empirical analyses focus on exploiting the cross-sectional variation.  

Our measure is distinct from measures of product market concentration. The correlation between labor market concentration (Labor_Market_HHI) and the fee-based audit product market concentration (Product_Market_HHI) is 0.1774. Figure 1, which reports the scatterplot of the natural logarithm of average labor market concentration and the natural logarithm of average product market concentration, further confirms that these two measures capture different underlying constructs. Table 1 shows the CBSAs with the highest (lowest) labor market HHI are Boulder, CO, Shreveport, LA, and Baton Rouge, LA (Wichita, KS, Oklahoma City, OK, and Tulsa, OK). In contrast, as shown in Table OA1 of the online appendix, the CBSAs with the most (least) concentrated product market are Lexington-Fayette, KY, Billings, MT, and Albuquerque, NM (Miami-Fort Lauderdale-West Palm Beach, FL, Los Angeles-Long Beach-Anaheim, CA, and Dallas-Fort Worth-Arlington, TX).  

### Measures of Audit Quality  

We use two proxies for audit quality, following prior studies (e.g., DeFond and Zhang 2014). Aobdia (2019b) shows that these measures predict audit practitioner assessments of audit quality. First, we use restatements. Restatement is an indicator variable that equals one if the fiscal year $t$ is restated, as per Audit Analytics.18 We expect audit offices with higher audit quality to have clients that are less likely to restate earnings (e.g., DeFond and Zhang 2014). Second, we proxy for audit quality using the discretionary accruals from the cross-sectional modified Jones model (e.g., Dechow, Sloan, and Sweeney 1995; Yu 2008; Aobdia and Petacchi 2023). We estimate the following regression model.  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{\frac{T A_{i,t}}{A s s e t s_{i,t-1}}=\delta_{0}+\delta_{1}\frac{1}{A s s e t s_{i,t-1}}+\delta_{2}\frac{\Delta R e v_{i,t}-\Delta A R_{i,t}}{A s s e t s_{i,t-1}}+\delta_{3}\frac{P P E_{i,t}}{A s s e t s_{i,t-1}}+\varepsilon_{i,t},}\end{array}
$$  

where $T A(T o t a l a c c r u a l s)_{i,t}=I B C_{i,t}-C F O_{i,t};I B C_{i,t}=$ Income before extraordinary items (obtained from the cash flow statement); $C F O_{i,t}{=}O A N C F_{i,t}$ (Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities) $-X I D O C_{i,t}$ (Extraordinary Items and Discontinued Operations); $A s s e t s_{i,t-1}=$ total assets in the preceding year; $\Delta R e v_{i,t}=$ change in revenues from the preceding year; $\Delta A R_{i,t}=$ change in accounts receivable from the preceding year; and $P P E_{i,t}=\mathrm{gross}$ value of property, plant, and equipment. We estimate this regression each year using all client firm-year observations with the same two-digit Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) code, with the requirement to have at least eight observations available. We use the absolute value of the residual $\varepsilon_{i,t}$ as our measure of absolute discretionary accruals (Accruals).  

### Sample Selection  

Our regression sample focuses on the Big 4 audit firms. Given their dominance in the audit market, the Big 4 are the main players in the labor market for public accountants and might also target different types of employees relative to smaller audit firms. We use the following procedures to select the regression sample. First, we begin with 54,247 client-year observations in Audit Analytics from 2010 through 2017. We then match every client company in Audit Analytics with Compustat. We require all measures of audit quality and control variables to be available. We are then left with 15,643 client-year observations. Second, we keep the 13,984 client-years audited by the Big 4. These client-years are audited by 268 local offices, of which PricewaterhouseCoopers has 65 offices, Ernst & Young has 70, Deloitte & Touche has 60, and KPMG has 73. Next, for these 268 audit offices, we match the city where the office is located, provided in Audit Analytics, with the CBSA of job postings and only keep audit offices where Big 4 firms have job postings. We end up with 261 audit offices in 104 cities during the 2010-2017 period, corresponding to 11,359 client-year observations.  

## IV. EMPIRICAL ANALYSES  

### Descriptive Statistics  

Table 2 reports the descriptive statistics. The mean (median) auditor labor market HHI at the CBSA-year level is 0.2684 (0.2552), above the 0.25 threshold for high concentration provided by the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ). The mean absolute value of discretionary accruals is 0.1415. The mean restatement is $14.85\%$ . An average client-year in the sample has total assets of $\$1.7$ billion, a leverage of $39.3\%$ , a return on assets of $10.35\%$ , capital expenditures $4.9\%$ of total assets, and sales growth of $8.3\%$  

### Labor Market Concentration, Skill Requirements, Effort, and Wages (RQ1)  

In this section, we examine how audit offices use labor market power in terms of skills and effort requirements, and wages (RQ1). We first examine the relation between labor market concentration and skill requirements in online job postings by estimating the following regression at the audit office-year level.  

$$
S k i l l s_{j,t}=\beta_{0}+\beta_{1}L a b o r\_M a r k e t\_H H I_{j,t}+\beta_{2}P r o d u c t\_M a r k e t\_H H I_{j,t}+\sum\beta_{l}A u d i t o r\_C h a r+A u S
$$  

$\begin{array}{r l}&{\mathrm{J}\kappa u t v a_{j,t}-p_{0}+p_{1}\bot u u v\sigma_{-}\iota\mathfrak{n}u r\kappa e\iota_{-}\iota\mathfrak{n}u\iota_{j,t}+p_{2}r\prime\sigma u u\mathfrak{u}\iota_{-}\iota\mathfrak{n}u r\kappa e\iota_{-}\mathfrak{n}u\iota_{j,t}+\sum\rho_{l}\iota\mathfrak{n}u u u u\sigma_{-}\mathfrak{c}\iota u u}\ &{\sum\beta_{m}C B S A_{-}C h a r+\sum\beta_{n}m e a n(C l i e n t_{-}C h a r)+A u d i t F i r m\:F E+Y e a r\:F E+\varepsilon_{j,t},\qquad(2)}\end{array}$ where the suffixes $j$ and $t$ correspond to audit offices and years, respectively. Skills measures skill requirements in job postings. Besides the number of skills, we are particularly interested in soft skills,19 because the auditing literature highlights the importance of soft skills, such as negotiation and interpersonal skills in determining the outcome of the audit, due to extensive auditor teamwork and interactions with clients (e.g., Nelson and Tan 2005; Knechel et al. 2013). The labor economics literature also documents a positive relation between the demand for soft skills and measures of performance (e.g., Deming and Kahn 2018). We use the following measures of skill requirements on job postings for each audit office in a given CBSA-year: (1) #Skill_ Category: the number of unique categories of skills;20 (2) Soft/All: the average ratio of the number of soft skills over the number of all skills; (3) Soft/Hard: the average ratio of the number of soft skills over the number of hard skills; (4) %Soft, the fraction of job postings that require soft skills; and (5) Yrs_Edu, the average number of minimum years of education. To the extent that labor market power exists in the audit profession, we expect Labor_Market_HHI to load positively. Product_Market_HHI, Auditor_Char, CBSA_Char, and Client_Char are product market concentration and control variables at the auditor-, CBSA-, and client-level, respectively. We also include audit firm and year fixed effects to control for unobserved timeinvariant audit firm effects and time trend. All variables are defined in Appendix A.  

We report the results in Table 3, Panel A. We find positive associations between labor market concentration and skill requirements. These results suggest that audit offices with greater labor market power demand more skills and are consistent with the finding of Hershbein and Macaluso (2018) and Hershbein et al. (2019) that labor market power raises skill requirements. In addition, the coefficients on Product_Market_HHI are generally insignificant, which confirms that labor market power is a distinct construct from product market concentration. We caveat that these results apply to newly hired auditors because of lack of data on incumbent auditor skills. However, incumbent auditors might also upgrade their skills more often through increased training, although we cannot measure this mechanism.  

Next, we focus on auditor effort. We acknowledge that measuring effort is difficult, and that while directly measuring the quality of effort is not possible, we can measure its quantity. Our measure can proxy for overall effort so long that the requirements for quantity and quality of effort are positively correlated. We use the total number of auditors working in an audit office, divided by the total assets under audit (#Employee/Assets) in millions or by total audit fees in millions (#Employee/Fees).21 The lower these measures, the more auditors in a given office need to work on a per client asset or fee basis. Thus, we expect to find negative associations with labor market concentration when using these effort measures in Model (2). To construct these measures, we obtain the LinkedIn employment records of all individual auditors as of the end of 2019. These snapshots include all individuals who ever worked in any audit office and show the history of all their past and current employments. We measure the number of audit personnel in each audit office in a year by counting the number of auditors whose employment histories show that they worked there at that time.22  

We report the results in columns (1) and (2) of Table 3, Panel B. We find significantly negative associations between labor market concentration and measures of effort. A onestandard-deviation increase in labor market concentration is associated with a 0.00036 (=- $0.004^{*}0.0901;$ decrease in the number of auditors per million dollars of client assets and a 0.709 $(=-7.873^{*}0.0901$ ) decrease in the number of auditors per million dollars of audit fees, which are equivalent to $10.6\%$ and $7.2\%$ decreases for an average firm, respectively. As these two measures are slightly skewed, we also use their natural logarithms in columns (3) and (4) of Table 3, Panel B and find similar results. Overall, these results are consistent with offices with greater labor market power demanding more effort from their individual auditors.  

Finally, we focus on auditor wages by estimating the following regression.  

$L o g(W a g e)_{j,k,t}=\beta_{0}+\beta_{1}$ Labor_Market. $\_H H I_{j,t}+\beta_{2}$ Product _Market _HHIj,t + β3Managerj,t + $\begin{array}{r}{\beta_{4}S e n i o r\_M a n a g e r/P a r t n e r_{j,t}+\sum\beta_{l}A u d i t o r\_C h a r+\sum\beta_{m}C B S A\_C h a r+}\end{array}$  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{\sum\beta_{n}m e a n(C l i e n t\_C h a r)+A u d i t F i r m F E+Y e a r F E+\varepsilon_{j,t},}\end{array}
$$  

where the suffixes $j,k$ and $t$ correspond to audit offices, job positions, and years, respectively. $L o g(W a g e)$ is the natural logarithm of the starting wage offered on a job position. The wage data are from the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL). When any organization in the U.S. hires an immigrant on an H-1B visa, it must file a labor condition application (LCA) with the DOL.23 Audit firms often hire skilled immigrants on H-1B visas and thus file a significant number of LCAs (Aobdia et al. 2018). We retrieve the LCAs filed by Big 4 audit firms on audit positions. We then match the locations of these LCAs to audit offices and keep those in cities where audit offices are located to ensure that the auditor labor market HHI measure is available. The variable of interest in this model is labor market concentration, Labor_Market_HHI.  

We report the results in Table 3, Panel C, where we add two indicator variables to control for job seniority: Manager (Senior_Manager/Partner), equal to one if the position is at the manager level (senior manager level or above) and zero otherwise. The coefficient on Labor_Market_HHI is not significantly different from zero, which does not provide evidence to suggest that audit offices in CBSAs with more concentrated labor markets pay different wages relative to those in less concentrated labor markets. In an additional untabulated test, we further control for CBSA fixed effects and find that Labor_Market_HHI loads negatively with a small coefficient, suggesting that intertemporal increases in labor market concentration within a CBSA are associated with modest decreases in wages. However, we caveat that a regression with CBSA fixed effects becomes a time-series specification that exploits only eight years of observations. This likely removes relevant variation of interest and raises concerns about multicollinearity. Thus, we do not include CBSA fixed effects in our empirical analyses.  

Overall, the results of higher skill requirements and effort at the same (or perhaps slightly lower) wages from audit offices in more concentrated markets indicate a departure of wages from marginal product of labor and suggest that audit offices in more concentrated labor markets may be more interested in recruiting more productive audit personnel and requiring higher effort rather than in reducing wages by large amounts.  

### The Effect of Labor Market Power on Audit Quality (H1)  

After providing evidence on how audit offices use labor market power, we focus on the effect of audit offices? labor market power on audit quality using the following regression.  

Audit Qualityi,jt  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{=\beta_{0}+\beta_{1}L a b o r\_M a r k e t\_H H J_{j,t}+\beta_{2}P r o d u c t\_M a r k e t\_H H I J_{j,t}+\beta_{3}O f f i c e_{-}S i z e_{j,t}}\ &{+\beta_{4}C o m p l e x i t y_{j,t}+\beta_{5}C B S A\_E x p e r t\_f_{j,t}+\beta_{6}E d u c a t i o n j_{j,t}+\beta_{7}\#U n i v e r s i t i v e_{j,t}}\ &{+\beta_{8}R e a l\_G D P_{j,t}+\beta_{9}C o s t\_L i v i n g_{j,t}+\beta_{10}S i z e_{i,j,t}+\beta_{11}M/\beta_{i,j,t}+\beta_{12}L e v e r a g e_{i,j,t}}\ &{+\beta_{13}R O A_{i,j,t}+\beta_{14}Q u i c k_{i,j,t}+\beta_{15}C A P E X\_{i,j,t}+\beta_{16}S D_{-}R e t_{i,j,t}+\beta_{17}S a l e s\_{-}G r o w t h_{i,j,t}}\ &{+\beta_{18}F o r e i g n_{i,j,t}+\beta_{19}M W_{i,j,t}+\beta_{20}F N D S R S E D_{i,j,t}+\beta_{21}I N T C O V i_{i,j,t}}\ &{+\beta_{22}M e r g e r_{i,j,t}+\beta_{23}I n f l u e n c e_{i,j,t}+\beta_{24}F i r s t\_T i m e_{i,j,t}+A u d i t F i r m F E}\ &{+Y e a r F E+C l i e n t I n d u s t r y F E\neq\varepsilon_{i,j,t},(4)}\end{array}
$$  

where the suffixes $i,j$ and $t$ correspond to clients, audit offices, and years, respectively. We use the two measures of audit quality discussed above, Restatement and Accruals, and expect negative associations between Labor_Market_HHI and these two measures.  

We control for Product_Market_HHI to rule out the possible confounding effects of the concentration of the audit product market on audit quality.24 We also add certain client and audit office-level characteristics that have been documented to affect audit quality (e.g., Francis and Yu 2009; Minutti-Meza 2013; DeFond, Erkens, and Zhang 2016; Hoopes et al 2018; Aobdia 2019b). We also control for macroeconomic conditions of the region in which the audit office is located, and include audit firm, year, and client industry fixed effects.25 We estimate the model using a logistic regression in column (1) and OLS in column (2). All continuous variables are winsorized at the top and bottom one percent and defined in Appendix A.  

Table 4 reports the results. As expected, we find significantly negative coefficients on Labor_Market_HHI in both columns (p-value $\leq5\%$ ). For example, the coefficient in column (1) is -0.962, suggesting that at the average of control variables, an increase in audit offices' labor market power from the $25^{\mathrm{th}}$ to the $75^{\mathrm{th}}$ percentile is associated with a decrease of 1.2 percentage points in the probability of restatement. Taken together, the results provide consistent evidence that audit offices? labor market power improves audit quality.  

### Cross-sectional Tests  

One concern about the results above is that they might be explained by unobserved factors correlated with both labor market concentration and audit quality. In this section, we mitigate this endogeneity concern by conducting several cross-sectional analyses. As suggested by Armstrong et al. (2022), cross-sectional tests can identify a subsample where correlated omitted factors are likely to exist but the causal effect of the variable examined is less pronounced and use this subsample as a placebo. Following this idea, we examine whether the relation between labor market concentration and audit quality is stronger when auditors have lower outside options such that labor market power of audit firms is likely to be more pronounced. The correlated omitted variables likely exist in both low- and high-outside option markets, but we expect the existence and effects of labor market power to be much weaker in markets with high outside options. Thus, we can use the results in the high-mobility/outside opportunity markets as placebo tests. We consider two types of outside options: (1) local substitute employment opportunities outside the audit profession, which refer to the ease for employees to move to non-auditing jobs in the same area, and (2) geographic mobility, which refers to the ease of an employee to move to a different location.  

We first partition the sample by various measures of local substitute employment opportunities. We proxy for these using (1) the average number of accounting-related postings by a public company, (2) the average number of tax-related postings by a public company, (3)  

the total number of tax- or consulting-related postings by Big 4 audit firms, and (4) the total number of finance-related postings, respectively in a CBSA-year.26 We expect employees to have lower local opportunities outside the audit profession when their offices are located in CBSAs with fewer numbers of these job postings and classify observations with equal-to- or above-median (below-median) value in the partitioning variable into the high (low) local substitute employment opportunity subsample. Table 5, Panels A to D report the results with Restatement in columns (1) and (2) and Accruals in columns (3) and (4) as the dependent variables. The relations between labor market concentration and measures of audit quality are only significant when local substitute employment opportunities are lower.  

Next, we partition the sample by various measures of geographic mobility, proxied by (1) the average distance between the area in which the labor market HHI is measured and other areas with the presence of at least one Big 4 office, (2) the local life quality using the Gallup well-being index of the area, and (3) the migration rate of the area, defined as (inflowoutflow)/total migration, respectively.27 We expect these measures to proxy for lower geographic mobility. Observations with equal-to- or above-median (below-median) value in the partitioning variable are classified into the low (high) mobility subsample. The results in Panels A to C of Table 6 consistently show that the effect of labor market power on audit quality is present only when employees? geographic mobility is lower.  

To further confirm that labor market power is more likely present when barriers to mobility are greater, we conduct similar cross-sectional analyses as in Tables 5 and 6 using the proxies for auditor skills, effort, and wages. We report the results in Tables OA2 to OA7 of the online appendix. The influence of labor market concentration on skills, effort, and wages is generally (but not always) only present when barriers to mobility are greater. Collectively, these cross-sectional analyses suggest that our results are unlikely to be explained by correlated omitted variables and provide additional evidence on the existence and effects of labor market power in auditing.  

### Further Analyses on Local Audit Office Differentiation  

According to Boal and Ransom (1997), labor market power can arise from oligopsony, where employers take each other's recruiting strategies as given (a la Cournot) or engage in tacit or explicit collusion in their recruiting practices, and differentiation. In the main analyses, we focus on oligopsony and use labor market concentration to capture the labor market power of all local audit offices. Another source of variation in labor market power may arise from differentiation of audit offices in the same area. Individual auditors might be more attracted to particular audit offices than others. From a theoretical standpoint, we can expand the analytical framework of Section II by adding a utility term, $B$ , that corresponds to office-level attributes, such as a higher labor market share, prestigious clients, or better training, and captures the dimensions along which audit offices are different from each other. Adding this differentiation factor into the model leads to the following equation in equilibrium: $p(W{+}B)$ e=pV(Labor_Market_HHI, s) (2). In this case, labor market power can be seen as depending on both area-level labor market concentration, Labor_Market_HHl, and office-level attributes, B. When the labor market power arising from these office-level atributes increases, to maintain Equation (2), this particular audit office can require greater skills $s$ or effort $e$ , or lower wages W. In other words, the implications of within-market differentiation are the same as those of cross-market labor market power, which is our initial focus. We note that Labor_Market_HHI and $B$ may reinforce each other, if preferences for specific offices are greater when labor market concentration is more salient. Overall, the discussion above suggests that either $B$ acts similarly to Labor_Market_HHI, or that Labor_Market_HHI and $B$ are complements and thus the results on Labor_Market_HHI are stronger in the subsample where $B$ exists.  

An important caveat with this expanded approach is that it assumes that labor market power arising from office-level attributes $B$ is similar among individual auditors. This would not occur if individuals had heterogeneous preferences.2α Thus, tests of particular audit office characteristics are likely more exploratory in nature. In this section, we explore whether labor market share, which captures the relative size of the office in the labor market of the locality, influences the relation between labor market concentration and audit quality. To the extent that offices with a higher share in the labor market are more desirable to individual auditors, we expect the results to be stronger for offices with a higher labor market share.  

In Table 7, we partition the sample by offices? labor market share, measured as auditor jobs posted by an audit office divided by the total auditor jobs posted by all top audit offices in the CBSA-year, and regress measures of audit quality on labor market power for offices with high and low labor market share separately. The effect of labor market power on audit quality is only present for offices with high labor market share. This finding is consistent with the idea that audit offices with a higher labor market share can more easily use labor market power. We also find some support on skills, effort, and wages in Tables OA8-10 of the online appendix, although the results are sometimes also significant for offices with lower labor market share.29 Overall, these results suggest that differentiation also likely exists in auditing labor markets.  

### Further Analyses on Auditor Experience  

We focus on auditor experience in Table 8, and expect to find stronger results on more experienced auditors because an emerging literature highlights the importance of mid-career auditors on audit quality (e.g., Kornberger et al. 2011; Aobdia et al. 2023). We construct two labor market power measures for lower and higher experienced auditors, HHl_LowerExp and HHI_HigherExp, based on job postings for audit positions that require experience of three years or less and more than three years, respectively. We find that both restatement and accruals relate negatively to HHI_HigherExp but do not relate to HHI_LowerExp.30  

### Robustness and Additional Tests  

We conduct a battery of ancillary tests to further mitigate endogeneity concerns and verify the robustness of our results. We first examine changes in audit quality in response to changes in labor market power arising from audit offices? client losses caused by clients being acquired during mergers and acquisitions. After a merger, the auditor of the target is typically dismissed (e.g., Firth 1999; Dhaliwal, Lamoreaux, Litov, and Neyland 2016).31 This client loss, plausibly exogenous to the quality of an audit office, can eventually diminish the office's capacity to hire labor, resulting in a potential increase in the labor market concentration of the CBSA where the affected office is located. To the extent that labor market power has a causal effect on audit quality, we expect a significant increase in the audit quality of all audit offices in the same CBSA after a client of an audit office is acquired.32  

We first identify 371 M&A deals in which a client firm is acquired by another company in a different CBSA. The treatment variable, Treated, equals one in the presence of such an acquisition event in a given CBSA and zero otherwise. The time variable, Post, is an indicator variable that equals one for all years following the event and zero otherwise. We report the results of the difference-in-differences analysis in Table OA11 of the online appendix. Panel A shows the effect of this shock on labor market concentration. We estimate this regression at the CBSA-year level, with CBSA and year fixed effects included. In column (1), the interaction TreatedxPost loads positively, suggesting that the audit labor market in the affected CBSA becomes more concentrated after the event. In column (2), we replace the dependent variable Labor_Market_HHI with Product_Market_HHI and do not find a positive change in response to client being acquired, which mitigates the possibility that audit quality is affected through a potential impact on audit market concentration rather than labor market power.  

If labor market power improves audit quality, we should observe an increase in the audit quality of clients in the affected CBSA in response to a client acquisition event. We regress audit quality on TreatedxPost, control variables, and fixed effects in Panel B. For a client in an affected CBSA to be included in the sample, it must meet the following conditions: (1) the affected CBSA does not have a client acquiring other companies (otherwise, the shock is contaminated), and (2) the client is not in the same industry as the focal client of the shock (otherwise, there might be extra auditor capacity available in this industry and this might contaminate the shock). The result of this difference-in-differences analysis suggests that after a client acquisition event that leads to a significant increase in labor market concentration, the audit quality of offices in the affected CBSA improves. In Panel C, we further show that the effects on labor market concentration and audit quality take place only after the client is acquired, suggesting that the pre-treatment trends are parallel. Overall, these results provide further support to the idea that labor market power has a causal effect on audit quality.  

Next, we use an alternative measure of audit quality and consider additional control variables in Table OA 12 of the online appendix. In Panel A, we proxy for audit quality with Meet-or-Beat, an indicator variable equal to one if the client firm meets or beats the zero earnings per share (EPS) benchmark by or within five cents, and zero otherwise. We find that client firms of auditors in more concentrated labor markets are less likely to meet or narrowly beat earnings targets. To the extent that Meet-or-Beat negatively relates to audit quality, this result further supports our main findings. In Panel B, following prior studies such as Lennox and Li (2014), we add an indicator variable for whether the client firm's earnings in the prior year is restated, Lag_Restatement, when the dependent variable is Restatement. The results remain robust. In Panel C, we conduct a placebo test by examining the relation between audit quality and labor market power in hiring advisory-related (non-auditing) employees. The idea is that if the audit quality results are driven by auditors hired in more concentrated labor market being more talented and exerting greater effort, we should not observe a relation between audit quality and labor market power in advisory positions. We construct an alternative measure of auditors? labor market power in advisory jobs, HHI_Advisory, based on the number of advisory jobs posted by local audit offices. We find that this measure is not related to our measures of audit quality, consistent with our prediction.  

In Panel D, we construct an alternative measure of labor market concentration using the audit-related job postings of all audit firms that appear in Audit Analytics during the sample period. We continue to find a positive relation between this measure of labor market power (HHI_Alt) and audit quality, albeit weaker. The weaker results might be explained by larger audit firms targeting different types of personnel relative to smaller audit firms, consistent with the segmentation that also exists in auditing product markets. In Panel E, we expand the sample from Big 4 to Top 8, Top 16, or all top audit firms used to construct the labor market concentration measure and re-run the main regression in Table 4 in each of the alternative samples. The results remain robust in these alternative samples. In Panel F, we conduct an office-level regression by using the average measures of audit quality and client characteristics and find consistent results. Finally, we partition the sample based on the number of Top 8 and 16 audit firms present in each local market. We cannot partition based on the Big 4 firms, because of lack of variation in the sample. The results (untabulated) are generally stronger when there are fewer audit firms, consistent with Cournot strategies being facilitated when the number of audit offices is lower.  

## V. CONCLUSION  

Recent literature in labor economics has increasingly paid attention to labor market concentration, a phenomenon in which reduced labor market competition can give employers the power to dictate wages (e.g., Azar et al. 2020; Benmelech et al. 2022). Firms with labor market power tend to have greater bargaining power in recruiting and retaining workers, as these workers have limited outside options (Berger et al. 2022). We focus on the audit profession and examine how audit offices use labor market power and whether audit offices with higher labor market power can provide higher-quality audits.  

We first provide evidence that audit offices in more concentrated labor markets comparatively require higher skills in their job postings and greater effort from their individual auditors, and their wages are similar or slightly lower, supporting the idea that labor market power exists in the audit profession. We then provide evidence that audit offices with greater labor market power provide higher-quality audit services. We further show that this result is only present when employees in the local labor market have fewer local outside employment opportunities or lower geographic mobility, consistent with labor market power explaining these results and mitigating omitted variable concerns.  

Taken together, our results suggest a short-run positive effect of labor market power in the audit profession, in the form of higher audit quality. Nevertheless, we caveat that the benefits of labor market concentration might not be permanent. In fact, large welfare losses of labor market power have been documented in other settings (e.g., Berger et al. 2022), and prospective employees might be tempted by alternative career options and have lower incentives to begin their careers in the audit profession. Thus, labor market power may serve as an explanation for the “talent shortage in public accounting (e.g., Schmalz 2024), and also be consistent with regulatory concerns about negative effects of audit firm concentration. While regulators are mostly concerned about how concentration might distort the supply of audit services,33 our results suggest that they might need to focus more on how concentration might reduce the atractiveness of the audit profession, and ultimately affect the supply of individual auditors in the long run. In general, we need more studies to better understand the causes of the apparent lack of interest of individuals to join the accounting profession.  

Our study is not without limitations. First, while we conduct extensive cross-sectional analyses following Armstrong et al. (2022) to mitigate alternative explanations such as the role of product market competition and endogeneity concerns, our tests nevertheless are associations between a measure of labor market concentration measured at the area level and proxies for labor market power and audit quality. Second, we can only estimate the effect of labor market power on audit quality for publicly traded corporations. While large audit firms significantly reduced their assurance services of non-public entities and even smaller public companies just after the implementation of Sarbanes Oxley in 2002, and prior to the start of our sample period in 2010 (Duguay, Minnis, and Sutherland 2020; Aobdia, Enache, and Srivastava 2021), we are unable to determine whether auditor wages, effort, and skill requirements are different across public and non-public clients. Third, our sample period takes place prior to the COVID-19 pandemic. Pandemic-driven changes in work conditions might have affected the relation between local job postings concentration and auditor wages, skills, and quality, especially if audit firms or other employers interested in hiring people with the skill set to become auditors allow their new hires to work remotely. Such changes may explain why competition for talent increased recently and auditor wages have significantly increased over the past few years. While we believe that these questions are important, we leave their answers to future research.

![](images/76615562cbafb4fa76e19c6625f0f79abcb8705b8715626c32f76c5cbeb262f4.jpg)  
FIGURE 1 Scatterplot of the Natural Logarithms of Average Labor Market Concentration (Labor_Market_HHI) and Average Product Market Concentration (Product_Market_HHI)  

We calculate the average labor market concentration (Labor_Market_HHI) and average product market concentration (Product_Market_HHI) across all years for each CBSA and then take their log forms. As defined in Appendix A, labor market Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (Labor_Market_HHI) at the CBSAyear level is calculated by computing the share of job openings of each audit office that posts job openings in the CBSA in a year and then summing the squared shares. Audit product market HerfindahlHirschman Index (Product_Market_HHI) at the CBSA-year level is calculated by computing the share of audit fees of each audit office in the CBSA in a year and then summing the squared shares. The size of the circles in the scatter is proportional to labor market size proxied by the average total number of job postings in a CBSA. The fitted line is from a regression weighing by labor market size proxied by the average total number of job postings in a CBSA; the estimated coefficients are displayed at the bottom of the figure, and the coefficient on the natural logarithm of product market concentration $(L o g$ Product Market HHI) is significant at the $1\%$ level.  

This table reports the average labor market concentration by CBSA, together with the average product market concentration, labor market size proxied by average CBSA-year count of job postings, and product market size proxied by average CBSA-year sum of audit fees (in millions).

 

This table examines how audit offices use their labor market power. Panel A presents the relation between labor market concentration and skill requirements. Using the jobs posted by an audit office in a year, we compute the dependent variables in columns (1)-(5) respectively as: (1) #Skill_Category: the number of unique categories of required skills, (2) Soft/All: the average ratio of the number of soft skills over the number of all skills required, (3) Soft/Hard: the average ratio of the number of soft skills over the number of hard skills required, $(4)\%S o f t$ : the fraction of jobs that require soft skills, and (5) Yrs_Edu: the average number of minimum years of education required. Panel B presents the relation between labor market concentration and several proxies for audit effort. The dependent variables are (1) #Employees/Assets: the ratio of the number of auditors in an audit office over total assets audited (in millions), (2) #Employees/Fees: the ratio of the number of auditors in an audit office over total fees earned (in millions), (3) Log(#Employees/Assets): the natural logarithm of #Employees/Assets, and (4) Log(#Employees/Fees): the natural logarithm of #Employees/Fees, respectively in columns (1)-(4). Panel C presents the relation between labor market concentration and auditor wages. The dependent variable is Log( Wage), the natural logarithm of wages offered by an auditor office in a year for specific positions. Labor_Market_HHI is the labor market Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI) calculated based on job postings in a CBSA-year. We estimate the regressions at the audit office-year level. Control variables as well as audit firm fixed effects and year fixed effects are included in all regressions. Standard errors are clustered at the audit office level and are reported in parentheses. \*\*\*, \*\*, and \* indicate significance at the $1\%$ $5\%$ ,and $10\%$ levels, respectively. Variables are defined in Appendix A.

This table examines the relation between labor market power and audit quality. The dependent variable in column (1) is Restatement, which is an indicator variable that equals one if any part of fiscal year t overlaps with a restated period identified in the Audit Analytics database, and zero otherwise. The dependent variable in column (2) is Accruals, which is the absolute value of discretionary accruals from the modified-Jones model. Labor_Market_HHl is the labor market Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI) calculated based on job postings in each CBSA-year. The regressions are estimated at the client firm-year level and include control variables and audit firm, year, and client industry fixed effects. Standard errors are clustered at the client firm level and reported in parentheses. \*\*\*, \*\*, and \* indicate significance at the $1\%$ $5\%$ ,and $10\%$ levels, respectively. Variables are defined in Appendix A.

This table reports the effects of local outside opportunities on the relation between labor market power and audit quality. We measure local outside opportunities as (1) the average number of auditrelated postings for a public company in a CBSA-year, (2) the average number of tax-related postings for a public company in a CBSA-year, (3) the total number of tax- or consulting-related postings by Big 4 audit firms in a CBSA-year, and (4) the total number of finance-related postings in a CBSAyear, respectively in Panels A-D. Samples are partitioned by the medians of the corresponding measures of local outside opportunities. The dependent variables are Restatement in columns (1) and (2) and Accruals in columns (3) and (4). The fixed effects and control variables are the same as in Table 4. Standard errors are clustered at the client firm level and reported in parentheses. \*\*\*, \*\*, and \* indicate significance at the $1\%$ $5\%$ ,and $10\%$ levels, respectively. This table examines the effects of geographic mobility on the relation between labor market power and audit quality. We measure mobility as (1) the inverse of the average distance between an audit office's home CBSA and other CBSAs with at least one Big 4 office, (2) the inverse of the life quality of the CBSA in which the audit office is located using the Gallup well-being index of the area, and (3) the inverse of the migration rate of the CBSA in which the audit office is located, which is defined as (inflow-outflow)/total migration, respectively in Panels A-C. Samples are partitioned by the medians of the corresponding mobility measures. The dependent variables are Restatement in columns (1) and (2) and Accruals in columns (3) and (4). Fixed effects and control variables are the same as in Table 4. Standard errors are clustered at the client firm level and reported in parentheses. \*\*\*, \*\*, and \* indicate significance at the $1\%$ $5\%$ and $10\%$ levels, respectively. Variables are defined in Appendix A.

This table examines the effects of labor market share on the relation between labor market power and audit quality. We measure labor market share as the auditor jobs posted by an audit office in a CBSAyear divided by the total number of auditor jobs posted by all the top audit offices in the CBSA-year. Samples are partitioned by the median of labor market share. The dependent variables are Restatement in columns (1) and (2) and Accruals in columns (3) and (4). The fixed effects and control variables are the same as in Table 4. Standard errors are clustered at the client firm level and reported in parentheses. \*\*\*, \*\*, and \* indicate significance at the $1\%$ $5\%$ ,and $10\%$ levels, respectively. Variables are defined in Appendix A.

### TABLE 8 Additional Test on Auditor Experience, Labor Market HHI, and Audit Quality  

This table examines the relation between labor market power and audit quality by seniority. We classify jobs that require experience of more than three years (three years or less) as higherexperienced (lower-experienced) positions. We then measure HHI separately for higher- and lowerexperienced positions and include HHI_HigherExp and HHI _LowerExp in the full-sample regression one at a time. The dependent variables are Restatement in columns (1) and (2) and Accruals in columns (3) and (4). The fixed effects and control variables are the same as in Table 4. Standard errors are clustered at the client firm level and reported in parentheses. \*\*\*, \*\*, and \* indicate significance at the $1\%$ $5\%$ ,and $10\%$ levels, respectively. Variables are defined in Appendix A.
