## E  Mathematical derivations  

This section provides detailed derivations of mathematical formulae that appear in the main text. It covers: (i) the household problem (Section E.1) (i) the firm problem (Section E.2), (i market equilibrium (Proposition 1.1) (Section E.3), (iv) general equilibrium and aggregation (Proposition 1.2) (Section E.4),(v) relationship between the labor share and concentration (Proposition 1.3) (Section E.5), (vi) closed form general equilibrium solution and scaling properties used in calibration (Section E.6), (vi) reduced form and structural labor supply elasticities (Section E.7), (vii) pass-through expression (Section E.8),(ix) expressions used in the discussion of corporate taxes (Section E.9), $(\mathbf{x})$ proofs of merger results (Proposition 3) (Section E.10).  

### E.1 Household problem - Section 1.2  

The household's problem is  

$$
\mathop{\operatorname*{max}}_{\left\{n_{i j t},c_{i j t},K_{t+1}\right\}}\sum_{t=0}^{\infty}\beta^{t}U\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)
$$  

where  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{N_{t}=\displaystyle\left[\int n_{j t}^{\frac{\theta+1}{\theta}}d j\right]^{\frac{\theta}{\theta+1}}}}\ {{}}\ {{n_{j t}=\displaystyle\left[\sum_{i\in j}n_{i j t}^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}}\right]^{\frac{\eta}{\eta+1}}}}\ {{}}\ {{C_{t}=\displaystyle\int\sum_{i\in j}c_{i j t}d j}}\end{array}
$$  

subject to the initial endowment $K_{0}>0.$ and the following budget constraint in each period, in which it takes all prices as given, these include the wage $w_{i j t}$ at all firms- $\cdot i j$ rental rate $R_{t}$ and profits $\Pi_{t}$ as given:  

$$
C_{t}+K_{t+1}-\left(1-\delta\right)K_{t}=\int\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j t}n_{i j t}d j+R_{t}K_{t}+\Pi_{t}
$$  

#### E.1.1 First order conditions  

· The first order conditions for consumption and capital give  

$$
U_{C}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)=\beta U_{C}\left(C_{t+1},N_{t+1}\right)\left[R_{t+1}+\left(1-\delta\right)\right]
$$  

· The first order conditions for consumption and labor supply to firm $i j$ gives  

$$
w_{i j t}=\frac{\partial n_{j t}}{\partial n_{i j t}}\frac{\partial N_{t}}{\partial n_{j t}}\left(-\frac{U_{N}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}{U_{C}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}\right)
$$  

#### E.1.2 Deriving supply system  

· Define the following terms. The market wage ${{w}_{j t}}$ is the number that satisfies $\begin{array}{r}{w_{j t}{n_{j t}}=\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j t}n_{i j t}}\end{array}$ Theaggregate wage $W_{t}$ is the number that satisfies $\begin{array}{r}{\pmb{W}_{t}\pmb{N}_{t}=\int\pmb{w}_{j t}\pmb{n}_{j t}d j}\end{array}$  

· We can write the first order condition as:  

$$
w_{i j t}n_{i j t}=\left(\frac{\partial n_{j t}}{\partial n_{i j t}}\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}\right)\left(\frac{\partial N_{t}}{\partial n_{j t}}\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}\right)\left(-\frac{U_{N}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}{U_{C}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}\right)N_{t}
$$  

· Using the labor disutility indexes, note that  

$$
\begin{array}{r l r}&{\frac{\partial n_{j t}}{\partial n_{i j t}}\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}=\left(\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}\right)^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}}}&{,\mathrm{therefore,}}&{\sum_{i\in j}\frac{\partial n_{j t}}{\partial n_{i j t}}\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}=1}\ &{\frac{\partial N_{t}}{\partial n_{j t}}\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}=\left(\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}\right)^{\frac{\theta+1}{\theta}}}&{,\mathrm{therefore,}}&{\displaystyle\int\frac{\partial N_{t}}{\partial n_{j t}}\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}d j=1}\end{array}
$$  

· Using these results and aggregating the first order condition over $i\in j,$ then over $j\in[0,1]$  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}{\mathrm{Aggregateover}i\in j:}&{w_{j t}n_{j t}=\left(\displaystyle{\frac{\partial N_{t}}{\partial n_{j t}}\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}}\right)\left(-\displaystyle{\frac{U_{N}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}{U_{C}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}}\right)N_{t}}\ {\mathrm{Aggregateover}j\in[0,1]:}&{W_{t}N_{t}=-\displaystyle{\frac{U_{N}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}{U_{C}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}}N_{t}}\ &{W_{t}=-\displaystyle{\frac{U_{N}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}{U_{C}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}}}\end{array}
$$  

· Aggregating the first order condition over markets $j\in[0,1].$ and then substituting the aggregate inverse labor supply curve back into the first order condition we can obtain the market supply curve:  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{w_{j t}n_{j t}=\displaystyle\left({\frac{\partial N_{t}}{\partial n_{j t}}}{\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}}\right)\left(-{\frac{U_{N}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}{U_{C}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}}\right)N_{t}}}\ {{{}}}\ {{w_{j t}n_{j t}=\displaystyle\left({\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}}\right)^{\frac{\theta+1}{\theta}}W_{t}N_{t}}}\ {{{}}}\ {{n_{j t}=\displaystyle\left({\frac{w_{j t}}{W_{t}}}\right)^{\theta}N_{t}}}\end{array}
$$  

which also implies that  

$$
\frac{\partial N_{t}}{\partial n_{j t}}\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}=\frac{w_{j t}n_{j t}}{W_{t}N_{t}}.
$$  

· Substituting this into the first order condition we can obtain the firm supply curve:  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{w_{i j t}n_{i j t}=\displaystyle\left(\frac{\partial n_{j t}}{\partial n_{i j t}}\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}\right)\left(\frac{\partial N_{t}}{\partial n_{j t}}\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}\right)\left(-\frac{U_{N}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}{U_{C}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}\right)N_{t}}}\ {{{}}}\ {{w_{i j t}n_{i j t}=\displaystyle\left(\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}\right)^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}}\left(\frac{w_{j t}n_{j t}}{W_{t}N_{t}}\right)W_{t}N_{t}}}\ {{{}}}\ {{n_{i j t}=\displaystyle\left(\frac{w_{i j t}}{w_{j t}}\right)^{\eta}\left(\frac{w_{j t}}{W_{t}}\right)^{\theta}N_{t}}}\end{array}
$$  

We can now compute expressions for the wage indexes $w_{j t}$ and $W_{t}$  

· Take the labor supply curve to the firm and aggregate  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{n_{i j}=\left(\displaystyle{\frac{w_{i j}}{w_{i j}}}\right)^{\eta}n_{j i}}}\ {{w_{i j}n_{j i}=w_{i j}^{1+\eta}w_{j i}^{-\eta}n_{j i}}}\ {{\displaystyle{\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j}n_{i j}=\left[\displaystyle{\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j}^{1+\eta}}\right]w_{j i}^{-\eta}n_{j i}}}}\ {{w_{j i}n_{j i}=\displaystyle{\left[\displaystyle{\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j}^{1+\eta}}\right]w_{j i}^{-\eta}n_{j i}}}}\ {{w_{j i}=\displaystyle{\left[\displaystyle{\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j}^{1+\eta}}\right]\mathrm{\prod_{i\inj}^{1+\eta}}}}}\end{array}
$$  

· Applying the same to the labor supply curve to the market we get  

$$
W_{t}=\left[\int w_{j t}^{1+\theta}d j\right]^{\frac{1}{1+\theta}}
$$  

● Therefore we have the set of results used in the body of the paper:  

$$
\begin{array}{l l}{{W_{t}=-\displaystyle\frac{U_{N}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}{U_{C}\left(C_{t},N_{t}\right)}}}&{{,n_{j t}=\left(\displaystyle\frac{w_{j t}}{W_{t}}\right)^{\theta}N_{t}\quad n_{i j t}=\left(\displaystyle\frac{w_{i j t}}{w_{j t}}\right)^{\eta}\left(\displaystyle\frac{w_{j t}}{W_{t}}\right)^{\theta}N_{t}}}\ {{W_{t}=\displaystyle\left[\int w_{j t}^{1+\theta}d j\right]^{\frac{1}{1+\theta}}}}&{{,w_{j t}=\displaystyle\left[\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j t}^{1+\eta}\right]^{\frac{1}{1+\eta}}}}\end{array}
$$  

· Using the above we can invert the labor supply curve to the firm in two steps. At the market level  

$$
w_{j t}=\left(\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}\right)^{\frac{1}{\theta}}W_{t}
$$  

and then at the firm level  

$$
w_{i j t}=\left(\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}\right)^{\frac{1}{\eta}}w_{j t}\quad,\quad w_{i j t}=\left(\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}\right)^{\frac{1}{\eta}}\left(\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}\right)^{\frac{1}{\theta}}W_{t}
$$  

● This is delivers the set of partial equilibrium conditions specified in the text in Section 1.2  

### E.2  Proof of Nash equilibrium expressions - Section 1.3  

· We can write the arguments of the firm's labor supply curve as the employment at competing firms in the same market which we denote by the vector $n_{-i j t},$ aggregateemployment $N_{t}$ and the aggregate wage $W_{t}$  

$\left\{\boldsymbol n_{i j t}^{*}\right\}_{i\in j}$ must satisfy the following set of conditions:  

$$
n_{i j t}^{*}=\arg\operatorname*{max}_{n_{i j t}}\widetilde{z}_{i j t}n_{i j t}^{\widetilde{\alpha}}-w\left(n_{i j t},n_{-i j t}^{*},W_{t},N_{t}\right)n_{i j t}\quad\forall i\in j
$$  

where the inverse labor supply curve is given by the household optimality condition:  

$$
w\left(n_{i j t},n_{-i j t}^{*},W_{t},N_{t}\right)=\left(\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}\right)^{\frac{1}{\eta}}\left(\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}\right)^{\frac{1}{\theta}}W_{t}\quad,\quad n_{j t}=\left[n_{i j t}^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}}+\sum_{k\neq i}n_{k j t}^{*\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}}\right]^{\frac{\eta}{\eta+1}}
$$  

● The first order condition for each firm is as follows, where we write the marginal revenue product of labor $m r p l_{i j t}=$ $\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{z}_{i j t}n_{i j t}^{\widetilde{\alpha}-1}$  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{m r p l_{i j t}=\displaystyle\frac{\partial w\left(n_{i j t},n_{-i j t}^{*},W_{t},N_{t}\right)}{\partial n_{i j t}}n_{i j t}+w\left(n_{i j t},n_{-i j t}^{*},W_{t},N_{t}\right)}}\ {{m r p l_{i j t}=w\left(n_{i j t},n_{-i j t}^{*},W_{t},N_{t}\right)\displaystyle\left[\frac{\partial w\left(n_{i j t},n_{-i j t}^{*},W_{t},N_{t}\right)}{\partial n_{i j t}}\frac{n_{i j t}}{w\left(n_{i j t},n_{-i j t}^{*},W_{t},N_{t}\right)}+1\right]}}\end{array}
$$  

The elasticity is  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\frac{\partial\log w\left(n_{i j t},n_{-i j t}^{*},W_{t},N_{t}\right)}{\partial\log n_{i j t}}=\frac{1}{\eta}+\left(\frac{1}{\theta}-\frac{1}{\eta}\right)\frac{\partial\log n_{j t}\left(n_{i j t},n_{-i j t}^{*}\right)}{\partial\log n_{i j t}}}\ &{\frac{\partial\log w\left(n_{i j t},n_{-i j t}^{*},W_{t},N_{t}\right)}{\partial\log n_{i j t}}=\frac{1}{\eta}+\left(\frac{1}{\theta}-\frac{1}{\eta}\right)\left(\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}\right)^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}}}\end{array}
$$  

· We can write this in terms of the payroll share of the firm. Using our expression for the labor supply curve to the firm  

$$
s_{i j t}=\frac{w_{i j t}n_{i j t}}{\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j t}n_{i j t}}=\frac{\left(\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}\right)^{\frac{1}{\eta}}\left(\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}\right)^{\frac{1}{\theta}}n_{i j t}}{\sum_{i\in j}\left(\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}\right)^{\frac{1}{\eta}}\left(\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}\right)^{\frac{1}{\theta}}n_{i j t}}=\frac{n_{i j t}^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}}}{\sum_{i\in j}n_{i j t}^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}}}=\left(\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}\right)^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}}.
$$  

This gives  

$$
\frac{\partial\log w\left(n_{i j t},n_{-i j t}^{*},W_{t},N_{t}\right)}{\partial\log n_{i j t}}=s_{i j t}\frac{1}{\theta}+\left(1-s_{i j t}\right)\frac{1}{\eta}
$$  

· Define the equilibrium inerse labor supply elasticity $\varepsilon_{i j t}^{*}$ as  

$$
\varepsilon_{i j t}^{*}=\left[s_{i j t}\frac{1}{\theta}+\left(1-s_{i j t}\right)\frac{1}{\eta}\right]^{-1}
$$  

· Then we can write the wage as  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{w_{i j t}^{*}=\mu_{i j t}^{*}m r p l_{i j t}}\ &{\mu_{i j t}^{*}=\cfrac{1}{s_{i j t}\frac{1}{\theta}+\left(1-s_{i j t}\right)\frac{1}{\eta}+1}}\ &{\mu_{i j t}^{*}=\cfrac{\left[s_{i j t}\frac{1}{\theta}+\left(1-s_{i j t}\right)\frac{1}{\eta}s_{i j t}\right]^{-1}}{\left[s_{i j t}\frac{1}{\theta}+\left(1-s_{i j t}\right)\frac{1}{\eta}\right]^{-1}+1}}\ &{\mu_{i j t}^{*}=\cfrac{\varepsilon_{i j t}^{*}}{\varepsilon_{i j t}^{*}+1}}\end{array}
$$  

● This is delivers the set of partial equilibrium conditions specified in the text in Section 1.3  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{w_{i j t}^{*}=\mu_{i j t}^{*}m r p l_{i j t}}}\ {{\mu_{i j t}^{*}=\displaystyle\frac{\varepsilon_{i j t}}{\varepsilon_{i j t}+1}}}\ {{\varepsilon_{i j t}^{*}=\displaystyle\left[s_{i j t}\displaystyle\frac{1}{\theta}+\left(1-s_{i j t}\right)\displaystyle\frac{1}{\eta}\right]^{-1}}}\end{array}
$$  

### E.3 Proof of Proposition 1.1  

● Collect terms in the labor supply curve that are common to allfirms in the market, $\pmb{x}_{j}:=\pmb{w}_{j}^{\theta-\eta}\pmb{W}^{-\theta}\pmb{N}$ · We have the following conditions  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{m r p l_{i j}=\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{z}_{i j}n_{i j}^{\widetilde{\alpha}-1}}\ &{\quad\quad\quad n_{i j}=w_{i j}^{\eta}\times\pmb{x}_{j}}\ &{\quad\quad w_{i j}=\mu\left(s_{i j}\right)m r p l_{i j}}\end{array}
$$  

· Substituting the labor supply curve into the $m r p l_{i j}$ definition, and then the pricing condition into the labor supply curve for $w_{i j}$ wehave  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{m r p l_{i j}=\left[\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{z}_{i j}\mu\left(s_{i j}\right)^{-\eta\left(1-\widetilde{\alpha}\right)}x_{j}^{\widetilde{\alpha}-1}\right]\times m r p l_{i j}^{-\eta\left(1-\widetilde{\alpha}\right)}}}\ {{m r p l_{i j}=\left[\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{z}_{i j}\mu\left(s_{i j}\right)^{-\eta\left(1-\widetilde{\alpha}\right)}x_{j}^{\widetilde{\alpha}-1}\right]^{\frac{1}{1+\eta\left(1-\widetilde{\alpha}\right)}}}}\end{array}
$$  

·Substiting this back into the optmiality condition:  

$$
w_{i j}=\left[\mu\left(s_{i j}\right)\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{z}_{i j}\right]^{\frac{1}{1+\eta(1-\widetilde{\alpha})}}\times x_{j}^{-\frac{1-\widetilde{\alpha}}{1+\eta(1-\widetilde{\alpha})}}=\left[\mu\left(s_{i j}\right)\widetilde{z}_{i j}\right]^{\frac{1}{1+\eta(1-\widetilde{\alpha})}}\times g\left(x_{j}\right)
$$  

● The definition of the payroll share, combined with the labor supply curve gives  

$$
s_{i j}=\frac{w_{i j}n_{i j}}{\sum_{k\in j}w_{k j}n_{k j}}=\frac{w_{i j}\left(\frac{w_{i j}}{w_{j}}\right)^{\eta}\left(\frac{w_{j}}{W}\right)^{\theta}N}{\sum_{k\in j}w_{k j}\left(\frac{w_{k j}}{w_{j}}\right)^{\eta}\left(\frac{w_{j}}{W}\right)^{\theta}N}=\frac{w_{i j}^{\eta+1}}{\sum_{k\in j}w_{k j}^{\eta+1}}=\frac{w_{i j}^{\eta+1}}{\sum_{k\in j}w_{k j}^{\eta+1}}.
$$  

· Under the above expression for $w_{i j}$  

$$
s_{i j}=\frac{\left[\mu\left(s_{i j}\right)\widetilde{z}_{i j}\right]^{\frac{\eta+1}{1+\eta\left(1-\widetilde{\alpha}\right)}}}{\sum_{k\in j}{\left[\mu\left(s_{k j}\right)\widetilde{z}_{k j}\right]^{\frac{\eta+1}{1+\eta\left(1-\widetilde{\alpha}\right)}}}}.
$$  

·Now recall that $\widetilde{z}_{i j}$ is the firm productivity under the firm's optimal capital decision, and &is the corresponding exponent  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{y_{i}=z_{i}\left(k^{*}\left(n_{i},z_{i},R\right)^{1-\gamma}n_{i}^{\gamma}\right)^{\alpha}=\widetilde{z}_{i}n_{i}^{\widetilde{\alpha}}}}\ {{\widetilde{z}_{i}=\left[1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha\right]z_{i}^{\frac{1}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}}\left(\displaystyle\frac{\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}{R}\right)^{\frac{\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}}}}\ {{\widetilde{\alpha}=\displaystyle\frac{\gamma\alpha}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}}}\end{array}
$$  

·Substituting these in  

$$
s_{i j}=\frac{\left[\mu\left(s_{i j}\right)^{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}z_{i j}\right]^{\frac{\eta+1}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha+\eta(1-\alpha)}}}{\sum_{k\in j}{\left[\mu\left(s_{k j}\right)^{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}z_{k j}\right]^{\frac{\eta}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha+\eta(1-\alpha)}}}}
$$  

● This is the expression in Proposition 1.1, which holds for all firms $i$ in market $j,$ and is independent of aggregates.  

· Note that in the limit as $\gamma\rightarrow1,$ then we can check that we obtain the no-capital expression from above  

$$
s_{i j}=\frac{\left[\mu\left(s_{i j}\right)z_{i j}\right]^{\frac{\eta+1}{1+\eta\left(1-\alpha\right)}}}{\sum_{k\in j}{\left[\mu\left(s_{k j}\right)z_{k j}\right]^{\frac{\eta+1}{1+\eta\left(1-\alpha\right)}}}}
$$  

Additionally in the limit with $\alpha\rightarrow1$ ,wehave  

$$
s_{i j}=\frac{\left[\mu\left(s_{i j}\right)z_{i j}\right]^{\eta+1}}{\sum_{k\in j}\left[\mu\left(s_{k j}\right)z_{k j}\right]^{\eta+1}}
$$  

· In the limit $\alpha\rightarrow1$ with $\gamma<1$  

$$
s_{i j}=\frac{\left[\mu\left(s_{i j}\right)^{\gamma}z_{i j}\right]^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta+\gamma}}}{\sum_{k\in j}\left[\mu\left(s_{k j}\right)^{\gamma}z_{k j}\right]^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta+\gamma}}}
$$  

### E.4 Proof of Proposition 1.2  

· We proceed in three steps.  

● First, consider an economy with a single nest, with a single elasticity of substitution $\eta,$ and consider the case of labor as the only input into production with decreasing returns $\alpha\in(0,1]$  

● Our starting point is the following set of equations, where we can take the markdown as exogenous. These describe firm level (i) output, (i) labor supply, (i) labor demand optimality, (iv) marginal revenue product:  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{y_{i}=z_{i}n_{i}^{\alpha}}\ {n_{i}=\left(\displaystyle\frac{w_{i}}{w}\right)^{\eta}n}\ {w_{i}=\mu_{i}m r p l_{i}}\ {\displaystyle\imath r p l_{i}=\alpha z_{i}n_{i}^{\alpha-1}}\end{array}
$$  

· We then have two aggregation conditions: (i) output, (ii) wage index  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{y=\displaystyle\int y_{i}d i}}\ {{\displaystyle w=\left[\int w_{i}^{1+\eta}d i\right]^{\frac{1}{1+\eta}}}}\end{array}
$$  

This set of 6 equations are our inputs to the following claim.  

· Claim $^{\ast}$ The aggregates $\{y,w,n\}$ can be written:  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{y=\omega z n^{\alpha}}\ {w=\mu\alpha z n^{\alpha-1}}\end{array}
$$  

where  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{z=\left[\displaystyle\int z_{i}^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}d i\right]^{\frac{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}{1+\eta}}}}\ {{\mu=\left[\displaystyle\int\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\mu_{i}^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}d i\right]^{\frac{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}{1+\eta}}}}\ {{\omega=\displaystyle\int\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\left(\frac{\mu_{i}}{\mu}\right)^{\frac{\eta\alpha}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}d i}}\end{array}
$$  

#### Proof  

● With decreasing returns to scale, we first solve out for the marginal revenue product of labor. Note that here we only multiply and divide by $z$  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{m r p l_{i}=\alpha z_{i}n_{i}^{\alpha-1}}\ &{m r p l_{i}=\alpha z_{i}\left(\left(\frac{w_{i}}{w}\right)^{\eta}n\right)^{\alpha-1}}\ &{m r p l_{i}=\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)w_{i}^{\eta(\alpha-1)}\left\langle\alpha z n^{\alpha-1}\right\rangle w^{\eta(1-\alpha)}}\ &{m r p l_{i}=\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)\mu_{i}^{\eta(\alpha-1)}m r p l_{i}^{\eta(\alpha-1)}\left\langle\alpha z n^{\alpha-1}\right\rangle w^{\eta(1-\alpha)}}\ &{m r p l_{i}=\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\mu_{i}^{-\frac{\eta(1-\alpha)}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\left\langle\alpha z n^{\alpha-1}\right\rangle^{\frac{1}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}w^{\frac{\eta(1-\alpha)}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}}\end{array}
$$  

· We can check that in the case of $\alpha=1$ then $m r p l_{i}=z_{i}$  

· Using this in the wage  

· Now aggregating:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{w_{i}=\mu_{i}m r p l_{i}}}\ {{w_{i}=\left(\frac{Z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\mu_{i}^{\frac{1}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\left\langle\alpha z n^{\alpha-1}\right\rangle^{\frac{1}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}w^{\frac{\eta(1-\alpha)}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}}}\end{array}
$$  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{w=\left[\int w_{i}^{1+\eta}d z\right]^{\frac{1+q}{1+q}}}\ &{w=\left[\int\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1+q}{1+q(1-q)}}\mu_{i}^{\frac{1+q}{1+q(1-q)}}d\right]^{\frac{1+q}{1+q}}\left\langle\alpha z\pi^{\alpha-1}\right\rangle^{\frac{1}{1+q(1-q)}}w^{\frac{1}{1+\left(1-q\right)}}}\ &{w^{\frac{1}{1+q\left(1-q\right)}}=\left[\int\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1+q}{1+q(1-q)}}\mu_{i}^{\frac{1+q}{1+q\left(1-q\right)}}d\right]^{\frac{1}{1+q}}\left\langle\alpha z\pi^{\alpha-1}\right\rangle^{\frac{1}{1+q\left(1-q\right)}}}\ &{w=\left[\int\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1+q}{1+q(1-q)}}\mu_{i}^{\frac{1+q}{1+\left(1-q\right)}}d\right]^{\frac{1+q}{1+q}}\times\left\langle\alpha z\pi^{\alpha-1}\right\rangle}\ &{w=\mu\left\langle\alpha z\pi^{\alpha-1}\right\rangle}\end{array}
$$  

●This delivers the first result. Note that if $\alpha=1$ then  

$$
\mu=\left[\int\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{1+\eta}\mu_{i}^{1+\eta}d i\right]^{\frac{1}{1+\eta}}
$$  

● Now turning to firm output, under the labor supply curve and labor demand:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{y_{i}=z_{i}n_{i}^{\alpha}}\ {y_{i}=z_{i}\left(\left(\frac{w_{i}}{w}\right)^{\eta}n\right)^{\alpha}}\ {y_{i}=z_{i}\left(\left(\frac{\mu_{i}m r p l_{i}}{w}\right)^{\eta}n\right)^{\alpha}}\ {y_{i}=z_{i}{\mu_{i}^{\alpha\eta}}m r p l_{i}^{\alpha\eta}\left(\frac{1}{w}\right)^{\alpha\eta}n^{\alpha}}\end{array}
$$  

· Using the previous expression for mrpli:  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{y_{i}=z_{i}\mu_{i}^{\alpha\eta}\left\{\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\mu_{i}^{-\frac{\eta(1-\alpha)}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\left\langle\alpha z n^{\alpha-1}\right\rangle^{\frac{1}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}w^{\frac{\eta(1-\alpha)}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\right\}^{\alpha\eta}\left(\frac{1}{w}\right)^{\alpha\eta}n^{\alpha}}\ &{y_{i}=z\left[\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{1+\frac{\alpha\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\mu_{i}^{\alpha\eta\left(1-\frac{\eta(1-\alpha)}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}\right)}\left\{\left\langle\alpha z n^{\alpha-1}\right\rangle w^{\eta(1-\alpha)}\right\}^{\frac{\alpha\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\left(\frac{1}{w}\right)^{\alpha\eta}\right]n^{\alpha}}\ &{y_{i}=z\left[\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\mu_{i}^{\frac{\alpha\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\left\{\left\langle\alpha z n^{\alpha-1}\right\rangle w^{\eta(1-\alpha)}\right\}^{\frac{\alpha\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\left(\frac{1}{w}\right)^{\alpha\eta}\right]n^{\alpha}}\end{array}
$$  

Given that we have shown that $\boldsymbol{w}=\mu\alpha z\boldsymbol{n}^{\alpha-1}$ we can use this to simplify $\{\cdot\}$  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{y_{i}=z\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\mu_{i}^{\frac{\alpha\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\left\{\left(\frac{w}{\mu}\right)w^{\eta(1-\alpha)}\right\}^{\frac{\alpha\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\left(\frac{1}{w}\right)^{\alpha\eta}n^{\alpha}}\ {y_{i}=z\left[\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\left(\frac{\mu_{i}}{\mu}\right)^{\frac{\alpha\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\right]n^{\alpha}}\end{array}
$$  

· Then aggregating:  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{y=\displaystyle\int y_{i}d i}\ &{y=\displaystyle\left[\int\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\left(\frac{\mu_{i}}{\mu}\right)^{\frac{\alpha\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}d i\right]\times\langle z n^{\alpha}\rangle}\ &{y=\omega\times z n^{\alpha}}\end{array}
$$  

This delivers the second result. Note that if $\alpha=1$ ,then  

$$
\omega=\int{\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{1+\eta}\left(\frac{\mu_{i}}{\mu}\right)^{\eta}d i}
$$  

· We stil need to show that the productivity term $z$ is correct. Notice that up to this point these derivations would hold under any $z$ . We pin down $z.$ by requiring that if there are no distortions $\boldsymbol{\mu}_{i}\mathrm{~=~}1$ for all firms), then the aggregate markdown is also $\mu=1$ . This requires:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{1=\left[\displaystyle\int\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{1+\eta}d i\right]^{\frac{1}{1+\eta}}}}\ {{\mathrm{}}}\ {{z=\left[\displaystyle\int z_{i}^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}d i\right]^{\frac{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}{1+\eta}}}}\end{array}
$$  

which also implies that in an undistorted economy, since $\omega=1$ , then output is simply $y=z n^{\alpha}$  

· This also implies that in the expression for $\mu$ and the expression for $\omega_{.}$ the productivity terms are well-defined weights:  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\mu=\left[\displaystyle\int\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\mu_{i}^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}d i\right]^{\frac{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}{1+\eta}},\quad\displaystyle\int\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}d i=1}\ &{\omega=\displaystyle\int\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\left(\frac{\mu_{i}}{\mu}\right)^{\frac{\alpha\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}d i\qquad,\quad\displaystyle\int\left(\frac{z_{i}}{z}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}d i=1}\end{array}
$$  

·. Using the above results we can now turn to the nested economy.  

#### ·Inner nest  

- We take the same approach as above, starting with the isomorphic 6 conditions at the firm level and now those expressing market level aggregates:   
- Firm conditions: We have 4 conditions representing firm output, labor supply, labor demand, and the marginal revenue product of labor:  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{y_{i j}=z_{i j}n_{i j}^{\alpha}}}\ {{{}}}\ {{n_{i j}=\left(\displaystyle\frac{w_{i j}}{w_{j}}\right)^{\eta}n_{j}}}\ {{{}}}\ {{w_{i j}=\mu_{i j}m r p l_{i j}}}\ {{m r p l_{i j}=\alpha z_{i j}n_{i j}^{\alpha-1}}}\end{array}
$$  

- Market aggregates: We then have two aggregation conditions: (i) market output, (i) market wage index  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{y_{j}=\displaystyle\sum_{i\in j}y_{i j}}}\ {{}}\ {{w_{j}=\left[\displaystyle\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j}^{1+\eta}\right]^{\frac{1}{1+\eta}}}}\end{array}
$$  

- Following the same steps as above, it is clear that we can show that: Claim -The market aggregates $\left\{y_{j},w_{j},n_{j}\right\}$ canbewritten:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{y_{j}=\omega_{j}z_{j}{n}_{j}^{\alpha}}}\ {{\mathrm{}}}\ {{w_{j}=\mu_{j}\alpha z_{j}{n}_{j}^{\alpha-1}}}\end{array}
$$  

where  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{z_{j}=\left[\displaystyle\sum_{i\in j}z_{i j}^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\right]^{\frac{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}{1+\eta}}}}\ {{}}\ {{\mu_{j}=\left[\displaystyle\sum_{i\in j}\left(\frac{z_{i j}}{z_{j}}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\mu_{i j}^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\right]^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta}}}}\ {{\omega_{j}=\displaystyle\sum_{i\in j}\left(\frac{z_{i j}}{z_{j}}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\left(\frac{\mu_{i}}{\mu}\right)^{\frac{\eta\alpha}{1+\eta(1-\alpha)}}}}\end{array}
$$  

#### Outer nest  

- The solution to the inner nests allows us to establish a similar set of 6 conditions  

- Market level: We have 3 conditions representing market output, aggregate labor supply, market labor demand:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{y_{j}=\omega_{j}z_{j}n_{j}^{\alpha}}}\ {{\qquadn_{j}={\left(\frac{w_{j}}{W}\right)}^{\theta}N}}\ {{\qquadw_{j}=\mu_{j}\alpha z_{j}n_{j}^{\alpha-1}}}\end{array}
$$  

- Economy aggregates: We have two aggregation conditions: (i) aggregate output, (i) aggregate wage index  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\displaystyle Y=\int y_{j}d j}}\ {{\displaystyle W=\left[\int w_{j}^{1+\theta}d j\right]^{\frac{1}{1+\theta}}}}\end{array}
$$  

● Following the above steps again, we can obtain:  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{Y=\Omega Z N^{\alpha}}}\ {{}}\ {{W=\mu\alpha Z N^{\alpha-1}}}\end{array}
$$  

where  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{Z=\displaystyle\left[\int z_{j}^{\frac{1+\theta}{1+\theta\left(1-\alpha\right)}}\right]^{\frac{1+\theta\left(1-\alpha\right)}{1+\theta}}}}\ {{\mu=\displaystyle\left[\int\left(\frac{z_{j}}{Z}\right)^{\frac{1+\theta}{1+\theta\left(1-\alpha\right)}}\mu_{j}^{\frac{1+\theta}{1+\theta\left(1-\alpha\right)}}d_{j}\right]^{\frac{1+\theta\left(1-\alpha\right)}{1+\theta}}}}\ {{\Omega=\displaystyle\int\left(\frac{z_{j}}{Z}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta\left(1-\alpha\right)}}\left(\frac{\mu_{j}}{\mu}\right)^{\frac{\eta\alpha}{1+\eta\left(1-\alpha\right)}}\omega_{j}d j}}\end{array}
$$  

● This delivers the main expressions in Proposition 1.2, in the case of an economy without capital and decreasing return. tolabor.  

#### E.4.1 Adding capital  

· The value-added production function of the firm in our model is  

$$
y_{i}=z_{i}\left(k_{i}^{1-\gamma}n_{i}^{\gamma}\right)^{\alpha}
$$  

● The optimal choice of capital solves  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{k_{i}^{*}\left(z_{i},n_{i},R\right)=\arg\underset{k_{i}}{\operatorname*{max}}z_{i}\left(k_{i}^{1-\gamma}n_{i}^{\gamma}\right)^{\alpha}-R k_{i}}\ &{k_{i}^{*}\left(z_{i},n_{i},R\right)=\left(\frac{\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha z_{i}}{R}\right)^{\frac{1}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}}n_{i}^{\frac{\gamma\alpha}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}}}\end{array}
$$  

· We can substitute this back into output to obtain:  

$$
y_{i}=z_{i}^{\frac{1}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}\left(\frac{(1-\gamma)\alpha}{R}\right)^{\frac{(1-\gamma)\alpha}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}n_{i}^{\frac{\gamma\alpha}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}} 
$$  

· Note that in terms of factor payment shares, capital is competitively priced:  

$$
R k_{i}=\alpha\left(1-\gamma\right)y_{i}
$$  

· Combining these, profits are  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\pi_{i}=y_{i}-R k_{i}-w_{i}n_{i}}}\ {{\pi_{i}=\left[1-\alpha\left(1-\gamma\right)\right]y_{i}-w_{i}n_{i}}}\ {{\pi_{i}=\left[1-\alpha\left(1-\gamma\right)\right]z_{i}^{\frac{1}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}}\left(\displaystyle\frac{\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}{R}\right)^{\frac{\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}}n_{i}^{\frac{\gamma\alpha}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}}-w_{i}n_{i}}}\end{array}
$$  

We can write this as  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\pi_{i}=\widetilde{y}_{i}-w_{i}n_{i}}}\ {{\widetilde{y}_{i}=\widetilde{z}_{i}n_{i}^{\widetilde{\alpha}}}}\ {{\widetilde{z}_{i}=\left[1-\alpha\left(1-\gamma\right)\right]z_{i}^{\frac{1}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}}\left(\displaystyle\frac{\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}{R}\right)^{\frac{\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}}}}\ {{\widetilde{\alpha}=\displaystyle\frac{\gamma\alpha}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}}}\end{array}
$$  

· Note that this implies that  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\widetilde{y}_{i}=y_{i}-R k_{i}=\left[1-\gamma\left(1-\alpha\right)\right]y_{i}}}\ {{\mathrm{}_{y_{i}}=\left[\frac1{1-\gamma\left(1-\alpha\right)}\right]\widetilde{y}_{i}}}\end{array}
$$  

●Itshould therefore be clear that what we have btained so far in our aggregation results implies the follwing:  

1. Market level - At the market level, define $\begin{array}{r}{\widetilde{\pmb{y}}_{j}=\sum_{i\in j}\widetilde{\pmb{y}}_{i j},}\end{array}$ then  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\mathrel{\phantom{=}}\widetilde{\pmb{y}}_{j}=\omega_{j}\widetilde{z}_{j}\pmb{n}_{j}^{\widetilde{\alpha}}}\ &{\mathrel{\phantom{=}}\pmb{w}_{j}=\mu_{j}\widetilde{z}_{j}\widetilde{\alpha}\pmb{n}_{j}^{\widetilde{\alpha}-1}}\end{array}
$$  

where $\left\{\omega_{j},\mu_{j}\right\}$ are as before, except with $\widetilde{\alpha}$ in place of $\alpha$ and we define $\widetilde{z}_{j}$ as:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\widetilde{z}_{j}=\left[\displaystyle\sum_{i<j}\widetilde{z}_{i j}^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\widetilde{\alpha})}}\right]^{\frac{1+\eta(1-\widetilde{\alpha})}{1+\eta}}}}\ {{}}\ {{\mu_{j}=\left[\displaystyle\sum_{i\in j}\left(\frac{\widetilde{z}_{i j}}{\widetilde{z}_{j}}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\widetilde{\alpha})}}\mu_{i j}^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta}}\right]^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta}}}}\ {{\omega_{j}=\displaystyle\sum_{i\in j}\left(\frac{\widetilde{z}_{i j}}{\widetilde{z}_{j}}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta(1-\widetilde{\alpha})}}\left(\frac{\mu_{i}}{\mu}\right)^{\frac{\eta\widetilde{\alpha}}{1+\eta(1-\widetilde{\alpha})}}}}\end{array}
$$  

2. Aggregate level - At the aggregate level, define $\begin{array}{r}{\widetilde{Y}=\int\widetilde{y}_{j}d j,}\end{array}$ then  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\widetilde{Y}=\Omega\widetilde{Z}N^{\widetilde{\alpha}}}}\ {{{}}}\ {{W=\mu\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{Z}N^{\widetilde{\alpha}-1}}}\end{array}
$$  

where $\{\Omega,\mu\}$ are as before, except with $\widetilde{\alpha}$ in place of $\alpha$ , and we define $\widetilde{\mathbf Z}$ as:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\widetilde{Z}={\displaystyle\left[\int\widetilde{z}_{j}^{\frac{1+\theta}{1+\theta\left(1-{\widetilde{\alpha}}\right)}}\right]^{\frac{1+\theta\left(1-{\widetilde{\alpha}}\right)}{1+\theta}}}~}}\ {{\displaystyle\mu={\left[\int\left(\frac{\widetilde{z}_{j}}{\widetilde{Z}}\right)^{\frac{1+\theta}{1+\theta\left(1-{\widetilde{\alpha}}\right)}}\mu_{j}^{\frac{1+\theta}{1+\theta\left(1-{\widetilde{\alpha}}\right)}}d j\right]^{\frac{1+\theta\left(1-{\widetilde{\alpha}}\right)}{1+\theta}}}}}\ {{\Omega={\displaystyle\int\left(\frac{\widetilde{z}_{j}}{\widetilde{Z}}\right)^{\frac{1+\eta}{1+\eta\left(1-{\widetilde{\alpha}}\right)}}\left(\frac{\mu_{j}}{\mu}\right)^{\frac{\eta\widetilde{\alpha}}{1+\eta\left(1-{\widetilde{\alpha}}\right)}}}\omega_{j}d j}}\end{array}
$$  

· Now observe that when we aggregate capital  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\displaystyle{\cal K}=\int\sum_{i\in j}k_{i}d j}}\ {{\displaystyle{\cal K}=\int\sum_{i\in j}\left(\frac{\alpha\left(1-\gamma\right)y_{i}}{R}\right)d j}}\ {{\displaystyle{\cal R}{\cal K}=\alpha\left(1-\gamma\right)\int\sum_{i\in j}y_{i}d j}}\ {{\displaystyle{\cal R}{\cal K}=\alpha\left(1-\gamma\right){\cal Y}\quad(*)}}\end{array}
$$  

· Now note that  

$$
Y=\int\sum_{i\in j}y_{i j}d j=\int\sum_{i\in j}\left[{\frac{1}{1-\gamma\left(1-\alpha\right)}}{\widetilde{y}}_{i j}\right]d j={\frac{1}{1-\gamma\left(1-\alpha\right)}}\int\sum_{i\in j}{\widetilde{y}}_{i j}d j={\frac{1}{1-\gamma\left(1-\alpha\right)}}{\widetilde{Y}} 
$$  

· Substituting the aggregate output expression $\widetilde{Y}=\Omega\widetilde{Z}N^{\widetilde{\alpha}}$ , into the aggregate labor demand condition:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{W=\mu\tilde{\alpha}\tilde{Z}N^{\tilde{\alpha}-1}}\ {W=\mu\tilde{\alpha}\left(\frac{\tilde{Z}N^{\tilde{\alpha}}}{N}\right)}\ {W=\left(\frac{\mu}{\Omega}\right)\tilde{\alpha}\left(\frac{\tilde{Y}}{N}\right)}\ {W=\left(\frac{\mu}{\Omega}\right)\left(\frac{\gamma\alpha}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}\right)\left(\frac{\left[1-\gamma\left(1-\alpha\right)\right]Y}{N}\right)}\ {W=\gamma\alpha\left(\frac{\mu}{\Omega}\right)\frac{Y}{N}\quad(\ast\ast)}\end{array}
$$  

· The equations $(*)$ and $(\ast\ast)$ describe agregate factor demand for capital and labor and appear in Proposition 1.2. · The steady-state resource constraint is ${\cal{C}}=\Upsilon-\delta K,$ which requires no proof, and the steady-state Euler equation  

$1=\beta\left[R+(1-\delta)\right],$ these can be combined with optimal capital demand to yield:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{C=Y-\delta K}}\ {{C=Y-\frac\delta R R K}}\ {{C=\left[1-\frac\delta R\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha\right]Y}}\ {{C=\left[1-\frac\delta R\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha\right]\frac\tilde{Y}{1-\gamma\left(1-\alpha\right)}}}\ {{C=\left[1-\frac\beta{\beta\delta}\right]\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha\right]\frac\tilde{Y}{1-\gamma\left(1-\alpha\right)}}}\end{array}
$$  

where we denote the constant $s_{C},$ which is the consumption share of output. These expressions appear in the main text. This implies that given ${\pmb{\mu}},$ and $\Omega$ we can solve for equilibrium $\left\{\widetilde{Y},W,N,C\right\}$ from  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\displaystyle{\cal W}=\mu\tilde{\alpha}\tilde{Z}N^{\tilde{\alpha}-1}}~}\ {{\displaystyle{\cal W}=\frac{U_{N}\left(C,N\right)}{U_{C}\left(C,N\right)}}~}\ {{\displaystyle~{\cal C}=s_{C}\frac{\tilde{Y}}{1-\gamma\left(1-\alpha\right)}}~}\ {{\displaystyle\tilde{\gamma}=\Omega\tilde{Z}N^{\tilde{\alpha}}}}\end{array}
$$  

· In the case of $U_{N}/U_{C}=N^{\varphi}C^{-\sigma},$ as is the case under GHH $\left(\sigma=0\right.$ ) or CRRA preferences $\left(\sigma\ge1\right)$ ), then all aggregates can be solved in closed form using the following equations from top to bottom:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{N=\left[\left(\displaystyle{\frac{s_{c}}{1-\gamma\left(1-\alpha\right)}}\Omega\right)^{-\sigma\varphi}\left(\mathfrak{a}_{\mu}\right)^{\sigma}\overbrace{Z}^{(1-\sigma)\varphi}\right]^{1+\frac{1}{|s|}\cdot\left(1-\delta\right)+\varphi|}}}\ {{W=\mu\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{Z}N^{\widetilde{\nu}-1}}}\ {{\widetilde{Y}=\Omega\widetilde{Z}N^{\widetilde{\nu}}}}\ {{C=\displaystyle{\frac{s_{c}}{1-\gamma\left(1-\alpha\right)}}\widetilde{\gamma}}}\ {{\displaystyle Y=\frac{1}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}\widetilde{\mathfrak{T}}}}\ {{R=\displaystyle{\frac{1}{\beta}}-\left(1-\delta\right)}}\ {{K=\displaystyle{\frac{(1-\gamma)\alpha}{R}}\gamma}}\end{array}
$$  

· Note that in the case of no wealth-effects on labor supply $\sigma=0.$ , and we have the result, cited in the text, that the equilibrium aggregate employment and wage are independent of $\pmb{\Omega}$  

$$
N=\left[\tilde{\alpha}\mu\widetilde{Z}\right]^{\frac{\varphi}{1+\varphi(1-\tilde{\alpha})}}\quad,\quad W=\mu\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{Z}N^{\widetilde{\alpha}-1}
$$  

#### E.4.2 Production function  

· In the main tet of the paper we provide the above conditions, but instead with the output as follows, which we now derive.  

$$
Y=\Omega^{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}Z\left(K^{1-\gamma}N^{\gamma}\right)^{\alpha}
$$  

where we also need to specify $Z$  

· First we need to go remove the optimal capital decisions encoded in $\widetilde{z}_{i j}$ and consequently $\widetilde{z}_{j}$ and $\widetilde{Z}$  

●Recall that  

$$
\widetilde{z}_{i j}=\left(1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha\right)z_{i j}^{\frac{1}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}}\left(\frac{\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}{R}\right)^{\frac{\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}},\:\widetilde{z}_{j}=\left[\sum_{i\in j}\widetilde{z}_{i j}^{\frac{1+\eta}{1-\alpha}}\right]^{\frac{1+\eta\left(1-\overline{{\alpha}}\right)}{1+\eta}},\:\widetilde{Z}=\left[\int\widetilde{z}_{j}^{\frac{1+\theta}{1+\theta\left(1-\overline{{\alpha}}\right)}}d j\right]^{\frac{1+\theta}{1+\eta}}
$$  

·Substituting $\widetilde{z}_{i j}$ into $\widetilde{z}_{j},$ we can define market productivity as follows, which gives the following implication:  

$$
z_{j}:=\left[\sum_{i\in j}z_{i j}^{\frac{1+\eta}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\right]^{\frac{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha+\eta(1-\alpha)}{1+\eta}}\implies\widetilde{z}_{j}=(1-(1-\gamma)\alpha)z_{j}^{\frac{1}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}\left(\frac{(1-\gamma)\alpha}{R}\right)^{\frac{(1-\gamma)\alpha}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}
$$  

· We can do the same for market and aggregate productivity:  

$$
\pmb{Z}:=\left[\int z_{j}^{\frac{1+(1-\gamma)\alpha+\theta\left(1-\alpha\right)}{1+\theta\left(1-\alpha\right)}}d j\right]^{\frac{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha+\theta\left(1-\alpha\right)}{1+\theta}}\implies\widetilde{\pmb{Z}}=\left(1-(1-\gamma)\alpha\right)\pmb{Z}^{\frac{1}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}\left(\frac{(1-\gamma)\alpha}{R}\right)^{\frac{(1-\gamma)\alpha}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}\pmb{Z}^{\frac{1}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}\pmb{Z}^{\frac{1}{1+(1-\gamma)\alpha}}.
$$  

· Note that this implies that the relationship between $Z$ and $\widetilde{\mathbf Z}$ given in the text  

$$
{\pmb Z}=\left[\frac{R}{\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}\right]^{(1-\gamma)\alpha}\left[\frac{\widetilde{{\pmb Z}}}{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}\right]^{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha}
$$  

● Now return to the aggregate production function $\widetilde{Y}=\Omega\widetilde{Z}N^{\widetilde{\alpha}}$ and substitute in (i the definitions of $\widetilde{\alpha}$ (i) ${\tilde{\mathbf{Z}}},$ and, (ii) $\widetilde{Y}=\left[1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha\right]Y,$ (iv) the aggregate capital demand condition $R=\big(1-\gamma\big)\alpha\big(Y/K\big),$ thsi gives the expression in Proposition 1.2:  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\widetilde Y=\Omega\widetilde{Z}N^{\frac{7\alpha}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}}\ &{\widetilde Y=\Omega\left(1-(1-\gamma)\alpha\right)Z^{\frac{1}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}\left(\frac{(1-\gamma)\alpha}{R}\right)^{\frac{(1-\gamma)\alpha}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}N^{\frac{\gamma\alpha}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}}\ &{Y=\Omega Z^{\frac{1}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}\left(\frac{K}{Y}\right)^{\frac{(1-\gamma)\alpha}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}N^{\frac{\gamma\alpha}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}}\ &{Y=\Omega^{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}Z\left(K^{1-\gamma}N^{\gamma}\right)^{\alpha}}\end{array}
$$  

where we have the productivity terms which are described in the footnote of Proposition 1.2:  

$$
z_{j}=\left[\sum_{i\in j}z_{i j}^{\frac{1+\eta}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha+\eta(1-\alpha)}}\right]^{\frac{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha+\eta(1-\alpha)}{1+\eta}}\quad,\quad\mathbf{Z}=\left[\int z_{j}^{\frac{1+\theta}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha+\theta(1-\alpha)}}d j\right]^{\frac{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha+\theta(1-\alpha)}{1+\theta}}

### E.5  Proof of Proposition 1.3 - Labor share and concentration  

· Rearranging the above conditions immediately gives the labor share  

$$
L S:=\frac{\int\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j}n_{i j}d j}{\int\sum_{i\in j}y_{i j}d j}=\frac{W N}{Y}=\gamma\alpha\left(\frac{\mu}{\Omega}\right)
$$  

·Since $\mu$ and $\pmb{\Omega}$ are independent of the supply block of the model, then they are independent of aggregates and preferences, and so is the labor share. That is, we only have to solve market equilibria to compute the labor share.  

· We now show that the expression linking the labor share and aggregate $H H I^{w n}$ holds.  

· We can use 'tilde' objects and then scale up at the end:  

$$
\widetilde{l s}_{i j}=\frac{w_{i j}n_{i j}}{\widetilde{y}_{i j}}=\frac{w_{i j}n_{i j}}{\widetilde{z}_{i j}n_{i j}^{\widetilde{\alpha}}}=\widetilde{\alpha}\frac{w_{i j}}{\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{z}_{i j}n_{i j}^{\widetilde{\alpha}-1}}=\widetilde{\alpha}\frac{w_{i j}}{m r p l_{i j}}=\widetilde{\alpha}\mu_{i j}
$$  

· Therefore the inverse of the labor share is:  

$$
\widetilde{l s}_{i j}^{-1}=\frac{1}{\widetilde{\alpha}}\mu_{i j}^{-1}
$$  

· Note that from our earlier expression for the markdown:  

$$
\mu_{i j}^{-1}=s_{i j t}\left(\frac{1}{\theta}-\frac{1}{\eta}\right)+\frac{1}{\eta}+1=\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}+s_{i j t}\left(\frac{\theta+1}{\theta}-\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}\right)
$$  

· Now the market inverse labor share is  

$$
\widetilde{l s}_{i j}^{-1}=\frac{\sum_{i\in j}\widetilde{y}_{i j}}{\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j}n_{i j}}=\sum_{i\in j}\frac{w_{i j}n_{i j}}{\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j}n_{i j}}\frac{\widetilde{y}_{i j}}{w_{i j}n_{i j}}=\sum_{i\in j}s_{i j}\widetilde{l s}_{i j}^{-1}
$$  

which using the above, gives:  

$$
\widetilde{l s}_{i j}^{-1}=\frac{1}{\widetilde{\alpha}}\left[\left(1-h h i_{j}\right)\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}+h h i_{j}\frac{\theta+1}{\theta}\right]
$$  

where hhi; = Ziej sj  

· Then the aggregate labor share is as follows, where we use our definiton $\begin{array}{r}{H H I=\int s_{j}h h i_{j}d j}\end{array}$  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\widetilde{L S}=\left[\frac{\int\sum_{i\in j}y_{i j}d j}{\int\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j}n_{i j}d j}\right]^{-1}}\ &{\quad=\left[\int s_{j}\widetilde{l s}_{j}^{-1}d j\right]^{-1}}\ &{\quad\widetilde{L S}=\widetilde{\alpha}\left[H H I\left(\frac{\theta}{\theta+1}\right)^{-1}+\left(1-H H I\right)\left(\frac{\eta}{\eta+1}\right)^{-1}\right]^{-1}}\end{array}
$$  

·Now note that  

$$
\boldsymbol{Y}=\frac{1}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}\boldsymbol{\widetilde{Y}}
$$  

therefore  

$$
L S=\frac{W N}{Y}=\frac{W N}{\frac{1}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}\widetilde{Y}}=\left[1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha\right]\widetilde{L S},
$$  

so under $\widetilde{\alpha}=\alpha\gamma/\left(1-\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha\right)$ we have  

$$
L S=\alpha\gamma\left[H H I\left(\frac{\theta}{\theta+1}\right)^{-1}+(1-H H I)\left(\frac{\eta}{\eta+1}\right)^{-1}\right]^{-1}
$$  

This is the expression in Proposition 1.3.  

● This also established the following claims: (i) the moments $L S$ and $H H I$ are independent of aggregate preferences and shifters in labor supply and productivity which we study below $\widetilde{A}$ and ${\overline{{\varphi}}},$ since the capital share is $K S=\alpha\left(1-\gamma\right)$ then this is also independent of preferences, therefore (i) we can estimate the model without specifying aggregate preferences.  

### E.6  Scaling the economy  

· Here we prove our claim in the text that we can choose scaling parameters for productivity and labor supply that can always be chosen to match average firm size and average worker pay without affecting any of the other moments of the economy.  

· Suppose we add two constants to the above economy $\widetilde{A}$ and $\overline{{\varphi}}$ such that the firm production function after optimizing out capital and the aggregate labor supply curve are:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\displaystyle\widetilde{y}_{i j}=\widetilde{A}\widetilde{z}_{i j}n_{i j}^{\widetilde{\alpha}}}}\ {{\displaystyle W=-\frac{U_{N}\left(C,N\right)}{U_{C}\left(C,N\right)}=\overline{{\varphi}}^{-1/\varphi}N^{1/\varphi}C^{\sigma}}}\end{array}
$$  

· We claim that we can always choose these constants to match two moments of the data: average firm size, and average workerpay.  

· Note that the above labor supply curve obtains under either CRRA or GHH preferences, where GHH preferences are thecaseof $\sigma=0$  

$$
U(C,N)=\frac{C^{1-\sigma}}{1-\sigma}-\overline{{{\varphi}}}^{-1/\varphi}\frac{N^{1+\frac{1}{\varphi}}}{1+\frac{1}{\varphi}}\quad,\quad U(C,N)=u\left(C-\overline{{{\varphi}}}^{-1/\varphi}\frac{N^{1+\frac{1}{\varphi}}}{1+\frac{1}{\varphi}}\right)
$$  

· Note that this implies that the changes to the set of equilibrium conditions are that aggregate output, labor demand and labor supply are:  

$$
\begin{array}{r c l}{{}}&{{}}&{{\widetilde{Y}=\Omega\widetilde{A}\widetilde{Z}N^{\widetilde{\alpha}}}}\ {{}}&{{}}&{{}}\ {{}}&{{}}&{{W=\mu\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{A}\widetilde{Z}N^{\widetilde{\alpha}-1}}}\ {{}}&{{}}&{{}}\ {{}}&{{}}&{{N=\overline{{{\varphi}}}W^{\varphi}C^{-\sigma\varphi}}}\end{array}
$$  

Combined these imply the same expression for the labor share:  

$$
W N=\left(\frac{\mu}{\Omega}\right)\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{Y}
$$  

which gives  

$$
\widetilde{Y}=\frac{W N}{\left(\frac{\mu}{\Omega}\right)\widetilde{\alpha}}
$$  

. Consider the following two moments: (i) Average firm size (AveFirmSize), (i) Average worker pay (AveWorkerPay) · The average firm size in the economy is  

$$
A v e F i r m S i z e:=\frac{\int\sum_{i\in j}n_{i j}d j}{\int M_{j}d j}=\frac{\int\sum_{i\in j}\left(\frac{w_{i j}}{w_{j}}\right)^{\eta}\left(\frac{w_{j}}{W}\right)^{\theta}N d j}{\int M_{j}d j}
$$  

● Define the following:  

$$
\nu_{i j}:=\left(\frac{w_{i j}}{w_{j}}\right)^{\eta}\left(\frac{w_{j}}{W}\right)^{\theta}
$$  

Using this  

$$
A v e F i r m S i z e=\frac{\int\sum_{i\in j}\nu_{i j}d j}{\int M_{j}d j}N
$$  

· Denote $\begin{array}{r}{\pmb{\nu}=\int\sum_{i\in j}\nu_{i j}d j}\end{array}$  

· The average worker pay in the economy is  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{A v e W o r k e r P a y=\displaystyle\frac{\int\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j}n_{i j}d j}{\int\sum_{i\in j}n_{i j}d j}}}\ {{\mathrm{~}=\displaystyle\frac{W N}{A v e F i r m S i z e\times\int M_{j}d j}}}\ {{A v e W o r k e r P a y=\displaystyle\frac{W}{\nu}}}\end{array}
$$  

We can re-write these:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{N=A v e F i r m S i z e\times\displaystyle\frac{\int M_{j}d j}{\nu}}}\ {{W=A v e W o r k e r P a y\times\nu}}\end{array}
$$  

· Claim - The aggregate $\nu$ is independent of all other aggregates including the shifters $\widetilde{A}$ and $\overline{{\varphi}}$ - Using our above results, but now including the shifter terms:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{\displaystyle\left(\frac{w_{i j}}{w_{j}}\right)=\frac{\mu_{i j}\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{z}_{i j}\widetilde{A}n_{i j}^{\widetilde{\alpha}-1}}{\mu_{j}\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{z}_{j}\widetilde{A}n_{j}^{\widetilde{\alpha}-1}}}\ {\displaystyle\left(\frac{w_{i j}}{w_{j}}\right)=\left(\frac{\mu_{i j}\widetilde{z}_{i j}}{\mu_{j}\widetilde{z}_{j}}\right)^{\frac{1}{1+\eta(1-\widetilde{\alpha})}}}\end{array}
$$  

and using a similar approach at the market level:  

$$
\left(\frac{w_{j}}{W}\right)=\left(\frac{\mu_{j}\widetilde{z}_{j}}{\mu\widetilde{Z}}\right)^{\frac{1}{1+\theta(1-\widetilde{\alpha})}}
$$  

- Therefore we have the following equation which implies that $\nu_{i j}$ is independent of aggregates including the shifi parameters $\widetilde{A}$ and $\overline{{\varphi}}$  

$$
\nu_{i j}=\left(\frac{\mu_{i j}\widetilde{z}_{i j}}{\mu_{j}\widetilde{z}_{j}}\right)^{\frac{1}{1+\eta(1-\widetilde{\alpha})}}\left(\frac{\mu_{j}\widetilde{z}_{j}}{\mu\widetilde{Z}}\right)^{\frac{1}{1+\theta(1-\widetilde{\alpha})}}
$$  

· We can then write the following system of equations, which we describe below  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{N=A v e F i r m S i z e\times\frac{\int M_{j}d}{\nu}}\ &{W=A v e W o r k e r P a y\times\nu}\ &{\widetilde{Y}=\frac{W N}{\left(\frac{\mu}{\Omega}\right)\widetilde{\alpha}}}\ &{Y=\frac{\widetilde{Y}}{1-(1-\gamma)\alpha}}\ &{K=\frac{\left(1-\gamma\right)\alpha x}{R}}\ &{c=\gamma-\delta K}\end{array}
$$  

· Starting with a solution of the market equilibria, we can obtain $\left\{\pmb{\nu},\pmb{\Omega},\pmb{\mu}\right\}$ which we have proven are independent of aggregates and shifters $\left\{\widetilde{A},\overline{{\varphi}}\right\}$ . Then given data on $A v e F i r m S i z e^{D a t a}$ and AveWorkerPayData , we can put data into the first two expressions above, and use these to compute $N$ and $W$ . Given these we can use the remaining equations to compute all other aggregate quantities $\{Y,C,K\}$ . What remains is to choose $\widetilde{A}$ and $\overline{{\varphi}}$ to be consistent with these aggregates. For this we use the two conditions that have not been used above by themselves: output and labor supply  

$$
\widetilde{Y}=\Omega\widetilde{A}\widetilde{Z}N^{\widetilde{\alpha}}\quad,\quad N=\overline{{{\varphi}}}W^{\varphi}C^{-\sigma\varphi},

which imply that  

$$
\widetilde{A}=\frac{\widetilde{Y}}{\Omega\widetilde{Z}N^{\widetilde{\alpha}}}\quad,\quad\overline{{{\varphi}}}=\frac{N}{W^{\varphi}C^{-\sigma\varphi}}.
$$  

● Proceeding in this way we can always choose shifters $\widetilde{A}$ and $\overline{{\varphi}}$ in order to match data on average firm size and average worker pay.  

● Once these are pinned down, then the system of equilibrium conditions without the moment conditions can be solved. Going from top to bottom, the equilibrium is computed:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{N=\left[\overline{{{\varphi}}}\left(\frac{{s_{c}}}{{1-\gamma\left(1-\alpha\right)}}\Omega\right)^{-{\varphi_{\varphi}}}\left({{\chi}_{\mu}}{\varphi}\left(\tilde{A}\ Z\right)^{\left(1-\alpha\right)}\right)^{\frac{{1}+{\gamma}}{{\left]}+{\gamma}\left(1-\tilde{{\lambda}\right)}+{\varphi_{\varphi}}}}\right]}}\ {{W=\mu\tilde{\alpha}\tilde{Z}\tilde{Z}N^{\tilde{\alpha}-1}}}\ {{{\overline{{{\gamma}}}}=\tilde{\Omega}\tilde{A}\tilde{Z}N^{\tilde{\alpha}}}}\ {{C=\frac{{s_{c}}}{{1-\gamma\left(1-\alpha\right)}}\tilde{\gamma}}}\ {{{\overline{{{\gamma}}}}=\frac{1}{{1-\left(1-\gamma\right)}\alpha}\tilde{\gamma}}}\ {{R=\frac{1}{{\frac{\rho}{2}}}-\left(1-\delta\right)}}\ {{{\overline{{{\kappa}}}=\left(\frac{{1-\gamma}}{R}\right)}\pi}}\end{array}

### E.7  Reduced form labor supply elasticities  

● We derive the expression linking reduced form and structural labor supply elasticities in Section 2.1  

· Conisder the labor supply curve to the firm  

$$
n_{i j t}=\left(\frac{w_{i j t}}{w_{j t}}\right)^{\eta}\left(\frac{w_{j t}}{W_{t}}\right)^{\theta}N_{t}
$$  

● Consider a first order approximation around the Nash equilibrium following any change to firms in the market  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\Delta\log n_{i j t}=\eta\Delta\log w_{i j t}+(\theta-\eta)\sum_{k\in j}\frac{\partial\log w_{j t}}{\partial\log w_{k j t}}\bigg|_{n_{-k j t}^{*}}\Delta\log w_{k j t}}\ &{\Delta\log n_{i j t}=\eta\Delta\log w_{i j t}+(\theta-\eta)\sum_{k\in j}\frac{\partial\log w_{j t}}{\partial\log w_{k j t}}\bigg|_{n_{-k j t}^{*}}\Delta\log w_{k j t}}\end{array}
$$  

● Consider the labor supply curve to the firm  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{w_{i j t}=\displaystyle\left(\frac{n_{i j t}}{n_{j t}}\right)^{\frac{1}{\eta}}\left(\frac{n_{j t}}{N_{t}}\right)^{\frac{1}{\theta}}W_{t}}}\ {{\log w_{i j t}=\displaystyle\frac{1}{\eta}\log n_{i j t}+\left(\frac{1}{\theta}-\displaystyle\frac{1}{\eta}\right)\log n_{j t}+\mathrm{Aggregates}}}\end{array}
$$  

· Consider a first order approximation around the Nash equilibrium, denoted by asterisks, following any change to firms  

in the market  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{\displaystyle\Delta\log w_{i j t}=\frac{1}{\eta}\Delta\log n_{i j t}+\left(\frac{1}{\theta}-\frac{1}{\eta}\right)\sum_{k\in j}\frac{\partial\log n_{j t}}{\partial\log n_{k j t}}\Bigg|_{n_{-k j t}^{*}}\log n_{k j t}}\ {\displaystyle\Delta\log w_{i j t}=\left(\frac{1}{\eta}+\left(\frac{1}{\theta}-\frac{1}{\eta}\right)\frac{\partial\log n_{j t}}{\partial\log n_{i j t}}\Bigg|_{n_{i j t}^{*}}\right)\Delta\log n_{i j t}+\left(\frac{1}{\theta}-\frac{1}{\eta}\right)\sum_{k\neq i}\frac{\partial\log n_{j t}}{\partial\log n_{k j t}}\Bigg|_{n_{-k j t}^{*}}\Delta\log n_{k j t}}\ {\displaystyle\Delta\log w_{i j t}=\left(\frac{1}{\eta}+\left(\frac{1}{\theta}-\frac{1}{\eta}\right)s_{i j t}^{*}\right)\Delta\log n_{i j t}+\left(\frac{\eta-\theta}{\theta\eta}\right)\sum_{k\neq i}s_{k j t}^{*}\Delta\log n_{k j t}}\end{array}
$$  

· The definition of the reduced form labor supply elasticity in the text is  

$$
\epsilon_{i j t}=\frac{\Delta\log n_{i j t}}{\Delta\log w_{i j t}}
$$  

· Using the above approximation:  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\epsilon_{i j l}=\frac{\big(1-\frac{1}{\eta}\big(1-\frac{1}{\eta}\big)s_{i j l}^{*}\big)\Delta\log n_{i j l}+\Big(\frac{\eta-\theta}{b_{i j l}}\Big)\sum_{k\neq i}s_{k j l}^{*}\Delta\log n_{k j l}}{\Big(\frac{1}{\eta}+\Big(\frac{1}{\vartheta}-\frac{1}{\eta}\Big)s_{i j l}^{*}\Big)+\Big(\frac{\eta}{b_{i j l}}\Big)\Big(\sum_{k\neq i}s_{k j l}^{*}\Delta\log n_{k j l}\Big)}}\ &{\epsilon_{i j l}=\frac{\Big(\frac{1}{\eta}+\Big(\frac{1}{\vartheta}-\frac{1}{\eta}\Big)s_{i j l}^{*}\Big)\Big(-\Big(\frac{\eta-\theta}{b_{i j l}}\Big)s_{i j l}^{*}\Big)-1}{1+\Big(\frac{1}{\eta}+\Big(\frac{1}{\vartheta}-\frac{1}{\eta}\Big)s_{i j l}^{*}\Big)^{-1}\Big(\frac{\eta-\theta}{b_{i j l}}\Big)\Big\{\sum_{k\neq i}s_{k j l}^{*}\Delta\log n_{i j l}\Big\}}}\ &{\epsilon_{i j l}=\left\langle\frac{1}{1+\varepsilon_{i j l}^{*}\Big(\frac{\eta-\theta}{\vartheta}\Big)\Big\{\sum_{k\neq i}s_{k j l}^{*}\Delta\log n_{i j}\Big\}}\right\rangle\epsilon_{i j l}^{*}}\end{array}
$$  

· This gives the expression in the text.  

### E.8   Pass-through expression  

We derive the pass-through expression that appears in Section 3.1  

● Consider a firm's Nash equilibrium wage  

$$
w_{i j t}^{*}=\mu_{i j t}^{*}m r p l_{i j t}
$$  

Here we have  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{m r p l_{i j t}=\widetilde{\alpha}\widetilde{z}_{i j t}n_{i j t}^{\widetilde{\alpha}-1}}\ &{m r p l_{i j t}=\widetilde{\alpha}\frac{\widetilde{y}_{i j t}}{n_{i j t}}}\ &{m r p l_{i j t}=\widetilde{\alpha}\left[1-(1-\gamma)\alpha\right]\frac{y_{i j t}}{n_{i j t}}}\ &{m r p l_{i j t}=\widetilde{\alpha}\left[1-(1-\gamma)\alpha\right]v a p w_{i j}}\end{array}
$$  

·Where $v a p w_{i j t}$ is value-added per worker. Using this we have the equilibruim system  

$$
\log w_{i j t}^{*}=\log v a p w_{i j t}+\log\mu_{i j t}^{*}+\mathrm{Constant.}\quad\mathrm{for~all}i\in j
$$  

· In each labor market, the equilibrium markdown of a frm is a funtion of its share $s_{i j t}$ which we can write $s_{i j t}=$  

$\left(w_{i j t}/w_{j t}\right)^{\eta+1}$ Therefore wecan write $\mu_{i j t}=\mu^{*}\left(w_{i j t}^{*},w_{-i j t}\right)$ as a funtion o thefirms wageand ompetor wages · Consider a perturbation of any firm in the market's $v a p w_{k j t},$ then to a first order around the Nash equilibrium:  

$$
d\log w_{i j t}=d\log v a p w_{i j t}+\frac{\partial\log\mu\left(w_{i j},w_{-i j t}^{*}\right)}{\partial\log w_{i j}}\Bigg\vert_{w_{i j t}^{*}}d\log w_{i j t}+\sum_{k\neq i}\frac{\partial\log\mu\left(w_{i j},w_{-k j t}^{*}\right)}{\partial\log w_{k j}}\Bigg\vert_{w_{i j t}^{*}}d\log w_{k j t}
$$  

· Denote these elasticities $m_{i i}$ and $m_{i k},$ then we have  

$$
d\log w_{i j t}=\frac{1}{1-m_{i i}}d\log v a p w_{i j t}+\frac{1}{1-m_{i i}}\sum_{k\ne i}m_{i k}d\log w_{k j t}
$$  

We can compute these elasticities, computing the following one by one:  

$$
{\frac{\partial\log\mu_{i j}}{\partial\log w_{i j}}}={\frac{\partial\log\mu_{i j}}{\partial\log\varepsilon_{i j}}}{\frac{\partial\log\varepsilon_{i j}}{\partial\log s_{i j}}}{\frac{\partial\log s_{i j}}{\partial\log w_{i j}}}
$$  

1. The elasticity of the markdown with respect to the labor supply elasticity is  

$$
\frac{\partial\log\mu_{i j}}{\partial\log\varepsilon_{i j}}=\frac{\mu_{i j}}{\varepsilon_{i j}}
$$  

2. The elasticity of the elasticity with respect to the payroll share is  

$$
\frac{\partial\log\varepsilon_{i j}}{\partial\log s_{i j}}=-\left(\frac{\eta-\theta}{\theta\eta}\right)\varepsilon_{i j}s_{i j}
$$  

3. The elasticity of the payroll share with respect to the wage is  

$$
\frac{\partial\log s_{i j}}{\partial\log w_{i j}}=(1+\eta)\left(1-s_{i j}\right)
$$  

· Combined these give  

$$
\frac{\partial\log\mu_{i j}}{\partial\log w_{i j}}=-\mu_{i j}\left(\frac{\eta-\theta}{\theta\eta}\right)\left(1+\eta\right)s_{i j}\left(1-s_{i j}\right)
$$  

· We can also write the markdown only in terms of shares  

$$
\mu_{i j}=\frac{\theta\eta}{\left(1-s_{i j}\right)\theta+s_{i j}\eta+\theta\eta}
$$  

● Substituting this into the above:  

$$
m_{i i}=\frac{\partial\log\mu_{i j}}{\partial\log w_{i j}}=-\frac{\left(\eta-\theta\right)\left(1+\eta\right)s_{i j}\left(1-s_{i j}\right)}{\left(1-s_{i j}\right)\theta+s_{i j}\eta+\theta\eta}
$$  

· We can also compute the elasticity of the firms' markdown with respect to competitor wages. Proceeding as above  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{\displaystyle m_{i k}=\frac{\partial\log\mu_{i j}}{\partial\log w_{k j}}=\frac{\partial\log\mu_{i j}}{\partial\log\varepsilon_{i j}}\frac{\partial\log\varepsilon_{i j}}{\partial\log s_{i j}}\left\langle\frac{\partial\log s_{i j}}{\partial\log w_{k j}}\right\rangle}\ {\displaystyle\frac{\partial\log\mu_{i j}}{\partial\log w_{k j}}=\frac{\mu_{i j}}{\varepsilon_{i j}}\left\{-\left(\frac{\eta-\theta}{\theta\eta}\right)\varepsilon_{i j}s_{i j}\right\}\left\langle-\left(1+\eta\right)s_{k j}\right\rangle}\ {\displaystyle\frac{\partial\log\mu_{i j}}{\partial\log w_{k j}}=\mu_{i j}\left(\frac{\eta-\theta}{\theta\eta}\right)\left(1+\eta\right)s_{i j}\left\langle s_{k j}\right\rangle}\end{array}
$$  

· Then note that we have the following relationship between the two elasticities:  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{\displaystyle\sum_{k\neq i}\frac{\partial\log\mu_{i j}}{\partial\log w_{k j}}=\mu_{i j}\left(\frac{\eta-\theta}{\theta\eta}\right)\left(1+\eta\right)s_{i j}\left\langle\sum_{k\neq i}s_{k j}\right\rangle}}\ {{\displaystyle=\mu_{i j}\left(\frac{\eta-\theta}{\theta\eta}\right)\left(1+\eta\right)s_{i j}\left\langle1-s_{i j}\right\rangle}}\ {{\displaystyle\sum_{k\neq i}m_{i k}=-m_{i i}}}\end{array}
$$  

● Using this in the pass-through equilibrium expression:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{d\log w_{i j t}=\displaystyle\frac{1}{1-m_{i i}}d\log v a p w_{i j t}+\frac{1}{1-m_{i i}}\sum_{k\neq i}m_{i k}d\log w_{k j t}}\ {d\log w_{i j t}=\displaystyle\frac{1}{1-m_{i i}}d\log v a p w_{i j t}+\frac{\sum_{l\neq i}m_{i l}}{1-m_{i i}}\sum_{k\neq i}\frac{m_{i k}}{\sum_{l\neq i}m_{i l}}d\log w_{k j t}}\ {d\log w_{i j t}=\displaystyle\frac{1}{1-m_{i i}}d\log v a p w_{i j t}+\frac{-m_{i i}}{1-m_{i i}}\sum_{k\neq i}\frac{m_{i k}}{\sum_{l\neq i}m_{i l}}d\log w_{k j t}}\end{array}
$$  

· Now note that  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{\frac{m_{i k}}{\sum_{l\neq i}m_{i l}}=\frac{\mu_{i j}\left(\frac{\eta-\theta}{\theta\eta}\right)\left(1+\eta\right)s_{i j}s_{k j}}{\sum_{l\neq i}\mu_{i j}\left(\frac{\eta-\theta}{\theta\eta}\right)\left(1+\eta\right)s_{i j}s_{l j}}}}\ {{\frac{m_{i k}}{\sum_{l\neq i}m_{i l}}=\frac{s_{k j}}{\sum_{l\neq i}s_{l j}}=\frac{s_{k j}}{1-s_{i j}}}}\end{array}
$$  

Therefore we have  

$$
d\log w_{i j t}=\frac{1}{1-m_{i i}}d\log v a p w_{i j t}+\frac{-m_{i i}}{1-m_{i i}}\sum_{k\ne i}\frac{s_{k j}}{1-s_{i j}}d\log w_{k j t}
$$  

· Now define $\Omega_{i i}=1/\left(1-m_{i i}\right)$ . Using this:  

$$
d\log w_{i j t}=\Omega_{i i}d\log v a p w_{i j t}+(1-\Omega_{i i})\sum_{k\neq i}\frac{s_{k j}}{1-s_{i j}}d\log w_{k j t}
$$  

· Using the expression for $m_{i i}$ we can obtain an expression for $\Omega_{i i}$  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{m_{i i}=-\displaystyle\frac{\left(\eta-\theta\right)\left(1+\eta\right)s_{i j}\left(1-s_{i j}\right)}{\left(1-s_{i j}\right)\theta+s_{i j}\eta+\theta\eta}}}\ {{\Omega_{i i}=\displaystyle\frac{s_{i j}\left(\eta-\theta\right)+\theta\left(\eta+1\right)}{\left[1+\left(1+\eta\right)\left(1-s_{i j}\right)\right]s_{i j}\left(\eta-\theta\right)+\theta\left(\eta+1\right)}}}\end{array}
$$  

This gives the expression in Section 3.1 of the main text.  

### E.9 Corporate taxes  

· Consider a single firm $i,$ and assumes constant returns to scale.   
· Let the corporate tax rate be given by $\tau_{C}$ . Suppose that the firm can deduct some portion of its capital expenses $\lambda_{K}$ This corresponds to the fraction of capital expenses that are financed by long-term debt.  

· Accounting profits of the firm, on which taxes are based, are given by  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{\pi_{i}^{A}=z_{i}k_{i}^{1-\gamma}n_{i}^{\gamma}-w_{i}n_{i}-\underbrace{\lambda_{K}R k_{i}}_{\qquad}}\end{array}
$$  

· The economic profits of the firm are  

$$
\pi_{i}^{E}=z_{i}k_{i}^{1-\gamma}n_{i}^{\gamma}-w_{i}n_{i}-R k_{i}
$$  

● The after tax profits are given by  

$$
\pi_{i}=\pi_{i}^{E}-\tau_{C}\pi_{i}^{A}
$$  

· This gives, the following which reflects the idea that on net the firm pays corporate taxes on its total economic profits, and then is reimbursed for the taxes paid on capital financed by debt.  

$$
\pi_{i}=(1-\tau_{C})\left[z_{i}k_{i}^{1-\gamma}n_{i}^{\gamma}-w_{i}n_{i}-R k_{i}\right]+\tau_{C}\lambda_{K}R k_{i}
$$  

· Dividing by $(1-\tau_{C})$ , the firm maximizes  

$$
\frac{\pi_{i}}{1-\tau_{C}}=z_{i}k_{i}^{1-\gamma}n_{i}^{\gamma}-w_{i}n_{i}-\underbrace{\left(\frac{1-\tau_{C}\lambda_{K}}{1-\tau_{C}}\right)R k_{i}}_{\mathrm{Termis}>1}
$$  

· The effective rental rate of capital $\widetilde{R}\left(R,\tau_{C},\lambda_{K}\right)$ that the firm faces is now higher than $R$ due to the fact that not all of capital expenses can be deducted, while all of its labor expenses can. This causes the firm to take on a sub-optimal amount of capital. This lowers the marginal revenue product of other factors, including labor. If the firm could deduct all of its capital costs, then $\lambda_{K}=1$ , and the firm's input decisions are undistorted.  

● Substituting in the firm's capital decision into their production function gives  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{\displaystyle\frac{\pi_{i}}{1-\tau_{C}}=\widetilde{z}\left(z_{i},R,\tau_{C},\lambda_{K}\right)n_{i}-w_{i}n_{i}}}\ {{\mathrm{}}}\ {{\widetilde{z}\left(z_{i},R,\tau_{C},\lambda_{K}\right)=\gamma z_{i}^{\frac{1}{\gamma}}\left(\displaystyle\frac{1-\gamma}{\widetilde{R}\left(R,\tau_{C},\lambda_{K}\right)}\right)^{\frac{1-\gamma}{\gamma}}=\gamma z_{i}^{\frac{1}{\gamma}}\left(\displaystyle\frac{1-\tau_{C}}{1-\tau_{C}\lambda_{K}}\displaystyle\frac{1-\gamma}{R}\right)^{\frac{1-\gamma}{\gamma}}}}\end{array}
$$  

· The marginal product of labor $\widetilde{z}_{i}$ is now lower due to the presence of corporate taxes and deductibility of interest payments Ondebt.  

### E.10 Mergers - Proposition 3.1  

● In this section we prove the claims in Proposition 3.1. These are listed in a different order in Proposition 3.1, but here listed in the order that they are proved:  

1. Following a merger, the markdowns at the merged firms are equalized and depend on the total market share, $\mu_{1j}=\mu_{2j}=\mu\left(s_{1j}+s_{2j}\right)$  

2. Under either monopsony limit a merger has no effect on any labor market variables.  

3. The individual shares $s_{i j}$ of all non-merging firms increase. Therefore the total market share of merging firms falls.  

4. The wage index of non-merging firms decreases and employment index increases.  

5. Market wage $w_{j}$ and employment ${\pmb n}_{j}$ decline, so total market pay $\begin{array}{r}{w_{j}n_{j}=\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j}n_{i j}}\end{array}$ declines.  

6. The wages of both merging firms $w_{1j}$ and $w_{2j}$ decline. The wage index of merging firms decreases and employment index decreases.  

· Parts 1 and 2 we prove under decreasing returns to scale. The remainder we establish under constant returns to scale The proof of Part 3 is the most involved, and remaining parts follow from Part 3 in a straight-forward manner.  

#### E.10.1 Markdowns  

· Throughout we assume $M_{j}\geq3.$ and assign $i=1$ and $i^{\prime}=2$ to the two merging firms.  

● A merged firm chooses employment at both firms to maximize profits, where without loss of generality for this proof we can consider the case of a production function $f(\cdot)$ that already incorporates the (competitive) intermediate and capital choices  

$$
\operatorname*{max}_{n_{1j},n_{2j}}\left[f\left(z_{1j},n_{1j}\right)-w\left(n_{1j},n_{-1j}\right)n_{1j}\right]+\left[f\left(z_{2j},n_{2j}\right)-w\left(n_{2j},n_{-2j}\right)n_{2j}\right]
$$  

· When taking the first order condition, the firm understands that $n_{2j}$ appears in ${\pmb{n}}_{-1j}$ and vice versa.  

· The first order condition for $n_{1j}$ is as follows, where we use $m r p l_{1j}=f_{n}\left(z_{1j},n_{1j}\right)$ to denote the marginal revenue prodt of labor  

$$
\left(m r p l_{1j}-\frac{\partial w_{2j}}{\partial n_{1j}}n_{2j}\right)=\frac{\partial w_{1j}}{\partial n_{1j}}n_{1j}+w_{1j}
$$  

· Written this way we can see that in understanding that increasing $n_{1j}$ increases the wage at firm 2, maps into an effectiv reduction in productivity at firm 1.  

Recall that  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{w_{1j}=n_{1j}^{\frac{1}{\eta}}n_{j}^{\frac{1}{\theta}-\frac{1}{\eta}}X}}\ {{w_{2j}=n_{2j}^{\frac{1}{\eta}}n_{j}^{\frac{1}{\theta}-\frac{1}{\eta}}X}}\end{array}
$$  

●Using this expression  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{m r p l_{1j}-w_{1j}=\left(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\eta}+\left(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\theta}-\displaystyle\frac{1}{\eta}\right)s_{1j}\right)w_{1j}+\left(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\theta}-\displaystyle\frac{1}{\eta}\right)s_{1j}\frac{w_{2j}n_{2j}}{n_{1j}}}}\ {{m r p l_{1j}-w_{1j}=\left(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\eta}+\left(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\theta}-\displaystyle\frac{1}{\eta}\right)s_{1j}\right)w_{1j}+\left(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\theta}-\displaystyle\frac{1}{\eta}\right)s_{2j}w_{1j}}}\ {{m r p l_{1j}-w_{1j}=\left[\displaystyle\frac{1}{\eta}+\left(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\theta}-\displaystyle\frac{1}{\eta}\right)\left(s_{1j}+s_{2j}\right)\right]w_{1j}}}\end{array}
$$  

·Therefore $w_{1j}=\mu\left(s_{1j}+s_{2j}\right)m r p l_{1j}$ Note that the same algebra can be applied to firm 2. Therefore this establishes the first result:  

$$
\mu_{1j}^{\prime}=\mu_{2j}^{\prime}=\mu\left(s_{1j}^{\prime}+s_{2j}^{\prime}\right)
$$  

● Note that the above algebra generalizes in a straight-forward way to the case of an arbitrary set of firms merging. Let the set of merging firms be $A$ then  

$$
\mu_{i j}^{\prime}=\mu\left(s_{j A}^{\prime}\right)\quad s_{j A}^{\prime}=\sum_{i\in A}s_{i j}^{\prime}.
$$  

#### E.10.2  No effect of mergers in monopsony  

· Consider the above problem of the merged firm in a monopsonistically competitive labor market  

$$
\operatorname*{max}_{n_{1j},n_{2j}}\left[f\left(z_{1j},n_{1j}\right)-w\left(n_{1j}\right)n_{1j}\right]+\left[f\left(z_{2j},n_{2j}\right)-w\left(n_{2j}\right)n_{2j}\right]
$$  

· Here the wage depends on ${\pmb n}_{j}$ but since the firm is infintessimal, it does not internalize its effect on $\pmb{n}_{j}$  

● The first order condition for firm 1 employment is:  

$$
m r p l_{1j}=w^{\prime}\left(n_{1j}\right)n_{1j}+n_{1j}
$$  

● This is identical to the first order condition of firm 1 in the pre-merger economy. Therefore there is no effect at all on employment and wages.  

#### E.10.3 Shares of all non-merging firms increase. Therefore the combined share of merging firms falls.  

Groups - A useful concept is that of a grouping within a market. Split the firms in the market into those that merge $i\in A$ and hose that don't merge $i\in B$  

· Define the group-level employment and wage indexes:  

$$
n_{j G}=\left[\sum_{i\in G}n_{i j}^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}}\right]^{\frac{\eta}{\eta+1}}\quad,\quad w_{j G}=\left[\sum_{i\in G}w_{i j}^{\eta+1}\right]^{\frac{1}{\eta+1}}\quad,\quad G\in\{A,B\}
$$  

· It is straight-forward to use these definitions to show that the market indices are  

$$
\pmb{n}_{j}=\left[\pmb{n}_{j A}^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}}+\pmb{n}_{j B}^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}}\right]^{\frac{\eta}{\eta+1}}\quad,\quad\pmb{w}_{j}=\left[\pmb{w}_{j A}^{\eta+1}+\pmb{w}_{j B}^{\eta+1}\right]^{\frac{1}{\eta+1}}
$$  

● These can then be used to derive group level supply curves and share relationships:  

$$
\boldsymbol{\eta}_{j G}=\left(\frac{w_{j G}}{w_{j}}\right)^{\eta}\boldsymbol{n}_{j},\boldsymbol{w}_{j G}\boldsymbol{n}_{j G}=\sum_{i\in G}w_{i j}\boldsymbol{n}_{i j},\boldsymbol{s}_{j G}:=\frac{\sum_{i\in G}w_{i j}\boldsymbol{n}_{i j}}{\sum_{i\in j}w_{i j}\boldsymbol{n}_{i j}}=\sum_{i\in G}s_{i j}=\left(\frac{w_{j G}}{w_{j}}\right)^{\eta+1}=\left(\frac{n_{j G}}{n_{j}}\right)^{\frac{\eta+1}{\eta}}
$$  

· For individual firms, then we can allocate labor relative to the group, and derive a relative share $\widetilde{s}_{i G}$ ofgroupwages. which we can show is equal to overall market share divided by group market share.  

$$
n_{i j}=\left(\frac{w_{i j}}{w_{j G}}\right)^{\eta}n_{j G}\mathrm{~,~}\widetilde{s}_{i G}:=\frac{w_{i j}n_{i j}}{\sum_{i\in G}w_{i j}n_{i j}}=\left(\frac{w_{i j}}{w_{j G}}\right)^{\eta+1}=\frac{s_{i j}}{s_{j G}}
$$  

emmas - We can use these definitions to establish three Lemmas that will be useful in proving the remaining content of the roposition. Proofs for each Lemma is at the end of this appendix.

#### E.10.7 Proofs of Lemmas  

Lemma 1 - Consider some change in a market that directly effects some group of firms $i\in A$ .Then the shares of all other firms $i\in B=\mathbb{Z}\backslash A,$ change in the same direction.  

·Proof: Suppose not. Then there are two firms $i,k\in B$ such that $s_{i j}^{\prime}>s_{i j}$ and $s_{k j}^{\prime}<s_{k j}$   
· For fim $i,$ since $s_{i j}^{\prime}>s_{i j},$ then $\mu\left(s_{i j}^{\prime}\right)<\mu\left(s_{i j}\right)$ $w_{i j}^{\prime}<w_{i j}$ From $s_{i j}=\left(w_{i j}/w_{j}\right)^{1+\eta}$ the oly way that $s_{i j}^{\prime}>s_{i j}$ while $w_{i j}^{\prime}<w_{i j}$ isif the market wage decreased: $\dot{{\boldsymbol w}_{j}^{\prime}}<{\boldsymbol w}_{j}$   
· For firm $k,$ arguing the opposite implies $w_{j}^{\prime}>w_{j}$ This is a contradiction: $w_{j}$ can not have increased and decreased .  

Lemma 2 - Merging firms (Proof at the end of this appendix)  

1. In terms of wage changes: $\Delta\log w_{1}>\Delta\log w_{2}$  

· Since both firms' productivity is constant and both have the same markdown post-merger:  

$$
\Delta\log w_{1j}-\Delta\log w_{2j}=\underbrace{\log\mu\left(s_{2j}\right)-\log\mu\left(s_{1j}\right)>0}_{\operatorname{Since}z_{1j}>z_{2j}\mathrm{then}\mu\left(s_{1j}\right)<\mu\left(s_{2j}\right)}
$$  

2.The relatie shareof the most productie of the meging firms increases $\widetilde{s}_{1A}^{\prime}>\widetilde{s}_{1A}$  

·Since $\mu\left(s_{1}\right)<\mu\left(s_{2}\right)$ , then  

$$
{\frac{w_{1}^{\prime}}{w_{1}}}>{\frac{w_{2}^{\prime}}{w_{2}}}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad{\frac{w_{2}^{\prime}}{w_{1}^{\prime}}}<{\frac{w_{2}}{w_{1}}}
$$  

· Manipulating both sides  

$$
\begin{array}{r l r}&{}&{\frac{1}{1+\left(\frac{w_{2}^{\prime}}{w_{1}^{\prime}}\right)^{1+\eta}}>\frac{1}{1+\left(\frac{w_{2}}{w_{1}}\right)^{1+\eta}}}\ &{}&{\frac{w_{1}^{\prime1+\eta}}{w_{1}^{\prime1+\eta}+w_{2}^{\prime1+\eta}}>\frac{w_{1}^{1+\eta}}{w_{1}^{1+\eta}+w_{2}^{1+\eta}}}\ &{}&{\left(\frac{w_{1}^{\prime}}{w_{A}}\right)^{1+\eta}>\left(\frac{w_{1}}{w_{A}}\right)^{1+\eta}}\ &{}&{\tilde{s}_{1A}^{\prime}>\tilde{s}_{1A}}\end{array}
$$  

Lemma 3 - For non-merging firms, if $s_{i j}^{\prime}>s_{i j}$ then $n_{i j}^{\prime}>n_{i j}$  

● Proof: Firm profit is  

$$
\pi_{i j}=z_{i j}n_{i j}-w_{i j}n_{i j}=z_{i j}n_{i j}-\left(n_{i j}^{\frac{1}{\eta}}n_{j}^{\frac{1}{\theta}-\frac{1}{\eta}}X\right)n_{i j}
$$

## F  Estimation details and bias exercise  

### F.1Distribution of firms across markets  

We assume there are 5,000 markets. For computational reasons, we must cap the number of firms per market since the Pareto distribution has a fat tail. We set the cap equal to 200 firms per market. Our results are not sensitive to the number of markets or the cap on firms per market.  

Tradeable firm distribution. Figure F1 (left) plots the distribution from which we draw the number of firms per market, $M_{j}$ . The distribution is a mixture of a discrete mass point at $M_{j}=1$ and a Pareto distribution over the support $M_{j}\in[2,\infty]$ .The Pareto's shape, scale, and location parameters are set to minimize the distance with the first three moments of the tradeable firm distribution. The parameters, data moments, and simulated moments are in Table F1.  

Economy-wide firm distribution. Figure F1 (right) plots the economy-wide distribution from which we draw the number of firms per market, $M_{j}$ . The distribution is a mixture of a discrete mass point at $M_{j}=1$ and a Pareto distribution over the support $M_{j}\in[2,\infty]$ . The Pareto's shape, scale, and location parameters are set to minimize the distance with the first three moments of the economy-wide firm distribution. The parameters, data moments, and simulated moments are in Table F2.
